description:
What a gem of a restaurant, an intimate space great for first dates. the owner was so nice to accommodate a party I organized back In February and everything turned out perfectly. Thank you! 

Service was quick and the food was outstandingly rich in flavor, great presentation too!
author: Inna E.

description: Despite being packed in like sardines and higher-than-average prices, I would have given this place five stars back in the early '90s.  Then I had a meal that seemed like nobody cared anymore. I've been a few times to see if things had improved but, sadly, the thrill is still gone.  At least they solved their crowding problems.
author: Rob B.

description: There's only one thing I crave when it's cold out and that's the Tom Kha Gai soup at Thep Phanom. It's the best in the city, it's so comforting and delicious. Some other favorites are the Crying Tiger Salad, Green Curry, the Dancing Lady, and the Thep Thong. The staff is so friendly and welcoming. They also make good cocktails, like the lychee mojito. It's a great low-key spot to have good convo, listen to great covers, and enjoy delicious Thai food.
author: Michelle R.

description:
First things first: Groupons no longer accepted, restaurant.com certificates no longer accepted, that being said they do accept the yelp check in discount 

Atmosphere: very cute and comfortable, good for a first date or other romantic event

Servers: attentive, professional and speedy 

Da Food: Portions on the smaller end considering that prices aren't that low and entrees don't come with rice. That is a huge pet peeve of mine. Rice is cheap.....it should come with your entree. Just saying. We had the Three's Company (prawns, scallops and squid in a coconut milk sauce) the flavor was interesting like coconut milk meets fish sauce meets lemongrass. We also had the honey duck which was alright. It felt like duck from a Chinese butcher shop on a bed of spinach and broccoli. The sauce I think I could have made at home using vinegar, soy sauce and honey. All in all in not super wowed. In total we spent $40 and left partially full and partially satisfied.
author: Karen L.

description: Tasty food, attractively presented, and reasonably priced. Highly recommend.
author: Patricia L.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for 12 years and this place is a great comfort food spot. Food is always solid, clean, fresh ingredients. Today I ordered the duck curry, wasn't greasy or too oily. Husband ordered a prawn dish. Prawns were cooked well, not over cooked like you'd get in many other places.  Always great here!
author: I love t.

description:
Oh my, this isn't the first time I've been here, not by a long shot. It actually may be the first Thai restaurant I had been to after I moved away from my parents' house for the final time. It was back in 1987, and I was a cherubic bean counter for a bank. A college friend of mine had told me his favorite restaurant was this place, so I went and have been coming back on an infrequent basis ever since. Obviously I hadn't been since 2006 because I never Yelped it before, which amazes me because I feel I know this converted Victorian spot so well. The staff is still as friendly as ever, so I took Jamie W. for his first time there. Sadly, it was as still as a tomb when we were there on a rainy Saturday afternoon.

Bossa nova-style covers of Michael Jackson's hits were wafting from the muzak. Some worked like "Human Nature, others didn't like "Beat It". We went for three hearty dishes. First up was the $15 Sam Kasatr, one of my favorite of their specialty dishes, a combination plate of sauteed chicken, beef and pork with sliced bamboo shoots and seasoned with Thai spices (photo: http://bit.ly/28NEYPy). It went really well with their $16 Pineapple Fried Rice, quite a delectable sweet-and-savory treat served in a grilled half-pineapple with fried rice blended with yellow curry and mixed with shrimp, chicken, cashew nuts, raisin, onion and fried egg (photo: http://bit.ly/28Rmjpp).

I've had variations at other Southeast Asian restaurants, and this one was up there. Our last dish was the $12 Pad Se Ew with Chicken, a Thai classic with pan-fried noodles with fried egg and broccoli in a thick soy sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/28ONY9O). All the food reminded me that Thep Phanom is like my late mom. Yeah, I'd forget to call her. Sure, I didn't come home when I told her I would so she could do my laundry. But she would make me some nice dinner anyway, even though she hated to cook beyond heating up the Toshiba rice cooker. I guess I should come back here more often, Mom. But you should work on your health score. I mean 76, c'mon. No, Mom, I'm not being critical. Love ya...

FOOD - 4 stars...familiar Thai dishes better than I remembered
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...an old Victorian done up with some semi-kitschy Siamese decor
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...still friendly as ever
TOTAL - 4 stars...sorry Mom...I mean Thep Phanom...I'll call more often
author: Ed U.

description: They are open on weekend morning/afternoons, but as a pop up thai noodle bar. Very nice people working here. Got the salmon noodle dish with a choice of type of noodle.
author: Phoenix F.

description:
I used to love this place and used to come here all the time. When a Groupon for them came up I excitedly bought it but didn't have enough time to use it before it expired.

The Groupon said I could always still use the value I bought the Groupon for though so I went in there to spend my $30 original dollars. No dice though, they refused to accept it even though I showed them the Groupon and the terms and conditions- they just pretended they had never seen it nor had ever offered that deal. Even though I showed them the picture on my phone. "No! Never- maybe last year." (It expired in February.) 

Pretty ridiculous. Food is pretty good but slightly worse than Osha.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: Food was good. Higher quality than many other Thai places in the area. Had the pad Thai, vegi spring rolls and Cashew chicken. All tasty! Loved the cilantro on the cashew chicken. The food was not greasy or over sugary (problems I have found at nearly Thai places). I'd eat here again!
author: Rachael B.

description: It's been awhile since I have been to Thep Phanom but I remembered I enjoyed the restaurant and the food with a couple of my siblings. This past weekend I suggested this restaurant to a couple of friends who wanted to get together.  My gal friend loves Thai cuisine. Once we arrived she liked the intimacy and the decor of the place. When our other guy friend showed up we then ordered our food and the Frog Leap Sauvignon Blanc. Everyone very much enjoyed the dishes we shared: Basil Salmon, Pad Thai with Tofu and Thaitanic Beef spicy.  The food was delicious and the service was very pleasant.  It's a little off the beaten path in Lower Haight but worth the visit and most importantly my gal friend was happy I suggested to go here for dinner.  They do accept phone reservations.
author: Patrick L.

description: Always very good.  been coming here for years.  Very Fun to bring out of town guests because their decor is beautiful and cozy and charming.   Definitely a long time favorite in this ever changing neighborhood.   I recommend the pineapple fried rice!   And any curry.   Also, try their fun non-alcoholic drinks.  Thanks Thep!!!
author: Amanda C.

description:
This was a main draw restaurant in this neighborhood when I first moved here 25 years ago. The menu was extensive, creative, and the service was exceptional.  BUT, things change.

Went last night for a birthday dinner about 7-8PM. Only a few tables occupied. Appetizer menu was now heavy on deep fried stuff, and much of the wide variety of other dishes was reduced. 
Service was OK but not as friendly as prior visits. 
We were served an appetizer we did not order, and a main dish we DID order did not come. Soft drinks were big on ice; little on fluids.

I did bring up the switched items with the bill, and we got an apology and a $5 credit (only good for 1 month!!), but the impression was already cast. 

There are lots of Thai places in SF. Look for a good one!
author: Michael H.

description:
I love this place!!! So many unique thai dishes and absolutely delicious. We had the deep fried pumpkin (great presentation), fried pork, thep thong, pad thai shrimp, and tamarind fish. Everything was great but if I had to pick a favorite, definitely the tamarind fish...and the fried pumpkin...and the thep thong...nevermind I can't pick a favorite! 
And then the dessert! We had both the Kahlua creme brulee and the FBI (fried banana ice cream.) The Kahlua creme brulee is nice and light and the perfect amount of sweetness. The FBI was perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside with fresh fruit and ice cream to balance with fried banana. 
If you haven't been here yet, give it a try. You won't be disappointed!!
author: Taryn J.

description: Love the look of this place, good food and great service! Try the dancing lady and Tom yum!
author: Karissa A.

description:
Really liked this small corner restaurant! The free Chang beer with check-in is like.. the highlight and made us order more food to go with the beer :D

Crying Tiger: 2-3 stars (small plate, $7)
Not authentically tasting.. Good quality beef but they're missing the actual dipping sauce and roasted rice powder! 

South Sea (stir-fry seafood with eggplant): 4.5 stars (regular size, $14ish) 
Totally worth it! Hot stir-fry with lots of seafood, and really good seasoning! Tasted a bit Chinese rather than Thai though. Sprinkle lots of dried chili powder with it. Yumz

Papaya Salad: 3-4 stars (small plate, $6) 
Again, delicious, but missing the authenticity (needed a loooooot more spice and some crushed peanuts on top)

Spicy Prawn: 2-4 stars (small plate, $7)
This literally came with ONE prawn. :-( However, it was a really tasty prawn. Sauce was good too. Again, not spicy enough.

You might be a little confused by my ratings here. Here's what I think.. This place serves awesome food, it's just not 'real' Thai food. But their service and everything made a really pleasant date night. I would still come back and hangout or try a couple more of their taps-sized dishes, which not a lot of restaurants do nowadays. And I encourage you to come try some dishes out and add a looooot of chili flakes on everything ^_^
author: Maggie G.

description:
Sawadee kha!

I came here a couple nights ago and I was super impressed. After living in Chiang Mai for 5 months, I got accustomed to the quality and authentic flavors of the cuisine. I've only had Thai food 4 times since being back for over a year for the fear of being let down and disappointed. But that didn't happen here! 

We order the spicy calamari (not something I'd usually order at a Thai restaurant)- but it was cooked and seasoned to perfection. The sauce was tangy and spicy with hints of garlic. Just terrific.

The Thaitanic beef was amazing as well. Little hint of yellow curry? 

Last but not least- the pad kee mao was kicking off with so many flavors, especially after adding some more spice to it. Pro tip: ask for "prik nam pla" it's the fresh chilis cut up mixed with fish sauce. Goes great on everything.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: What a great place in Deboce Triangle.  Food is well made not over breaded and fried.  Good ingredients and friendly people.  Good wine choices.  Recommend for a good night with friends or a date
author: Paul L.

description: I have been here a couple times and always thought the food was good.  I saw a Groupon and decided to come back after many years.  My Groupon expired November 10 so I went on November 9 since I thought they would be busy.  They posted a sign saying no Groupons after October 31 and would not accept it.  As a small business owner myself this is just bad business.  We did nothing wrong and we're penalized because they did not meet their terms or have any flexibility.  The owners should be ashamed as I wasted time/money going there via uber. There are too many good Thai restaurants in the city and believe me I will tell all my friends to never go there.
author: Robert L.

description: ordered take out, which was on time and warm.  However the food was not spiced well for our tastes and portions were small.   Soup was the only dish that seemed flavorful enough.  we had not eaten here in a couple yeas but it has gone downhill since its hey days.
author: Brian M.

description: What an amazing place to have across the street from our apartment!! The staff was so, so friendly and welcoming and really made our dinner experience as memorable as possible. Tan is such a sweet lady and Patrick is a very nice waiter. We shared all our dishes with brown and white rice on the side and had Chang beer to wash it down. Tan was so incredibly nice to bring us a complimentary mango sorbet with a raspberry and mint leaves on top, just because we are neighbors!! Such a great Thai dinner, we can't wait to go back! Would recommend every time!
author: Andy L.

description:
Itsa solid 3 star joint, its A-ok, nothing GREAT but fortunately nothing truly BAD. I guess if I lived across the street from this joint, it would be a great place to grab dinner, as a destination Thai dinner place, me thinks not. 4 for dinner:

FOOD : 

Crispy Tofu: $9 - good rendition, the accompanying cucumber salad wasa nice complement 

Crispy Cresent Moon $9 (deep fried pumpkin) "A" for creatively served in a wine glass w/ sauce 

"3's Company" - $15 scallops/calimari/shrimp: the shrimp were prawn sized, the scallops were the tough and tiny bay version (I think maybe 2 were present) calamari (squid) was the most populous item. The coconut sauce was thin, as in like water. Despite the clever name, it was disappointing. 

The "Som Tum" $10 - spicy green papaya salad, good

Tom Yum Goong $11 spicy & sour prawn soup - good

Basil prawns $ 15 - nicely spiced, but the "prawns" were more like "shrimps" - size does matter. 

Rice - 3 X $5 served in a clever traditional Thai tube 

Deserts / drinks / fried bananas / etc (Thai Coffee, Tea) $ ? x 6 - ok - nothin great

SERVICE: nice waitresses... (lookin a little stressed)

$120 for dinner for 4 - itsa ok price for the joint... but since I like to tip big that skews the price
author: Matsuo U.

description:
We ordered two pad sew ew with beef. The flavor is almost non existent. It is mild and has mild flavors that are overwhelmed by the plain flavor of the beef. 

Oh and the service. The capacity was maybe 50% at best full however we sat for a good ten minutes before we had to ask for water. We did however have our cups prior!!! 

$12 of disappointment
author: Nathan A.

description: This is one of our favorites when we visit SF!  Well worth the Uber to that part of town.
author: Jason P.

description:
Tonight my Panang chicken came with an extra treat...a 12" long straight, black hair wrapped around a piece of broccoli. So, that was my last order from TP. I'm actually a very forgiving, understanding guy. That's why I gave them a second chance after the exact same situation about 6 months ago. It took 6 months or so for me to be able to think about eating Thai food again. Tonight might have been the last time EVER for me.

POSTSCRIPT: when I made the management aware of the situation, they offered to give me a gift certificate for that entree. But just that one entree. Even though it was the start of the meal, and my companions were nauseated by the thought of eating THEIR Panang chicken. In the end, it wasn't worth the communication struggle and we just went elsewhere.
author: Aaron B.

description: The food here is terrific! Consistently super tasty, perfectly spiced in my opinion, oh and the staff are super nice and wear cool outfits! :) I recommend the green curry, and the titanic beef! Also, they have Chang beer which I love - goes nicely with spicy food!
author: Kristin R.

description: Excellent service . Aries was great and take care of mind . I will be back . Food is delicious. Clean and good environment ^^
author: Zen S.

description:
This is my go to Thai spot in my neighborhood when I have some extra cash. It can get a little pricy if you are a big eater and drinker. If you are going out for a good dinner with a significant other this would be a good casual place. 

There stuffed chicken wings are amazing, and their grilled shrimp stuffed with crab meat is my favorite. Can't go wrong with Pineapple fried rice and pad thai. The drinks are strong and the food is good.
author: Sean M.

description: The new weekend breakfast menu is wonderful! I just had fantastic Eggs Benedict and I will be back again.
author: Daniel H.

description: The food here is a notch above most other Thai restaurants in town. I used to call it "Thep Phanomenal" because it was so good. However, last time I was in I was disappointed in the service. We ordered soup, salad, and a main dish--and they all came at once. By the time we finished the soup and salad the main dish was cold. That seems pretty basic, especially when there were very few customers at the restaurant. Second, our plates from the soup and salad just piled up in the middle of the table without anyone checking to remove them. That kind of thing just makes me tense while I'm dining, like when are they going to remove the dirty dishes already? So, longtime fave for food, appreciate the generous pours of the wine, but more attentive service would make this a place I would want to return to more frequently...otherwise, I'll just get their takeout!
author: Laura F.

description: I wish this place was good but is just simply is not. The people who work here are nice. That's it. The food is not good. Tasteless. And 1 order of veggie red curry + rice = $18 for take out!?
author: Gernaut A.

description: I liked the environment at thep-phanom. We tried their weeping lady dish which was similar to spicy chicken basil; ordered it moderately spicy which was definitely spicy, but tasty. Their rice options include the typical white and brown, but they also have a sticky rice option served in a small straw container. Pretty nice and varied wine selection. If I'm around the haight area more often, would definitely repeat.
author: Will H.

description: This place was awesome. My fiancé and I are vegan and they had so many delicious options. The vegetable coconut soup was the perfect thing for a chilly SF evening. I had the Thaitanic Tofu and it was so flavorful and delicious. Will definitely verbs know.
author: Hannah Z.

description: Zero stars. After an hour late, restaurant indicates *another* hour before delivery because they "have to cook the food"- I could've cooked dinner in that time. Completely unintelligible and unapologetic as I explain that I need to feed my children on a school night at 8:30pm. Ridiculous. We will never know whether the food is deserving of any rating, but the restaurant is worthy of nothing. I'm shocked that they  remain in business.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Dear Thep Phanom,

I only tasted one item, the Pad Thai with tofu.  Those five stars are for this dish.

When it arrived it looked a touch pale, a touch slimy, and not particularly impressive.

"Meh" I thought to myself "I suppose I just have so much incredible Thai in Hawaii that I cannot expect everywhere else to live up to my standards of excellence".

I begrudgingly placed a chopstick full in my mouth and....

It was the BEST Pad Thai I had ever eaten in my entire existence. The best.  So good I think about it, I fantasize about it, I want to to go to you right this moment.

And I am angry with you as I am now ruined.  RUINED.  All Pad Thai since you has been such a disappointment I think I will stop ordering it completely.  I can't suck anyone else's noodle into my mouth, only your glistening noodles can slide down my throat and grant me complete and utter ecstasy.

Ahhhh.

Ahem.  

So anyhow, your Pad Thai is wonderful and someday I will be back and order every single vegetarian dish you offer to see if they are equally orgasmic.  I mean, delicious.

Love,
Angela
author: Angela M.

description: Cancelled all promotions just in time for us to make the trek over. Zero customer service.
author: Eugene C.

description: The noodle and broccoli in their pad se ew are good, but the beef could be better.
author: Yuchen Z.

description: Came in with a group of people for dinner. Got seated, ordered food, and had to wait over 30 mins for the food to arrive. Food wasn't that great either. It taste really bland and there weren't any taste to the chicken at all. Seemed like they just threw a pinch salt and started stir-fry. Two of my friends ordered the same plate (pad see ew) and by comparing the portion mine looked smaller than theirs. Service was okay. Also, false advertisement. On Yelp it says 10% off for dine-in costumers. They even have it on display outside of the door. My friend asked about it and a worker said "we cant do it." The worst part is that when we split the check among 6 of us. He charged me extra. I only ordered pad see ew and Thai tea and the total is 16$ and with sales tax it's 17.40$. And I just noticed they charged me 20.53$ in my card without tips.
author: Sandra Z.

description:
$12 for dry pad see ew. Need more sauce, noodles shouldn't be stuck together. 

They also charge .10 cents for the paper bag for my pick up. 

I personally try to stay away from establishments that nickel & dime and pass all cost to customers on top of the price.
author: Gloria T.

description:
Taste: 3 or less
Presentation: above 3
Service: just under 3
Music: at least 4
Overall: 3 or 3 1/2
In a word: "quirky"

DON'T BOTHER turning 21 for the mixed drinks. Despite all 3 servers standing before me to confirm that my "Muay Thai Mojito" was not the virgin version... puh-lease. They need to stop associating one of my favorite sports with this non-kickin', non-punchin' drink.

Only about the first third of my time was spent consuming my dish x beverage. I didn't want to leave the music, so I slowed way down and got into the salad (which I'd previously cast aside) and rice. The salad eventually vaporized, so I ordered a second dish x beverage and kept groovin' to covers of all-time hits till ~15 min before closing.

Future plan (if there is a future): Sit at the bar. Get one entree or two smaller dishes. Any beverages except cocktails. Limitless time to jam to the elevator music.

Notable decor:
Every waiter's "I Heart Thep Phanom" or "Waller x Fillmore" t-shirt.
Hen stuffed animal behind the bar.
Medieval Times curtains.
Huge wall painting.
author: Dan B.

description: food was actually grrreat, flavors were amazing. i give 4 stars because i asked for extra spicy, and i didn't get it. very disappointed for that. i didn't want to offend by asking for chili flakes, but c'mon that doesn't even make up for the layers of true thai spiciness. very sad. another downer was that our server forgot about us, after we asked for the bill. like for 10 minutes.  :( oh well.
author: Kit U.

description: I live close by and this has become my go-to spot for Thai food. The staff is really friendly and welcoming, and the ambiance is exactly what you want in a friendly neighborhood restaurant. I have tried a few dishes here and all were great. I strongly recommend the Tom Yum soup. It's pretty incredible. The salt and pepper beef appetizer is also definitely worth partaking in. All in all, this place is fantastic. Hands down a better choice than their competitors on Haight.
author: Hannah B.

description: Great Curry and service!  The order online app is easy and always ready quickly.
author: Allie L.

description:
Why does this place only have 3.5 stars?!?! I honestly don't understand. 

Thep Phanom is an amazing thai restaurant with very tasty thai food.  The ambiance is warm and intimate.  The service is very good, too! Great for a date night or dinner out with friends.

Their thaitanic beef is a must try!  Spacy and delicious!!!

I would come back here every week if I didn't have a care about weight gain!
author: Suzanna F.

description: Had the chicken pad thai and the papaya salad.  The chicken pad thai was mediocre.  Not bad, jist nothing to rave about. no heat at all, and more tofu than chicken.  the Papaya salad was very fresh and delicious. My frind got the curry chicken and it was just ok. Definitely a watered down american-ized version of thai cuisine. Ben thai is much better in my opinion but in a different part of town.
author: Kyle M.

description: Great restaurant that my SF friends always take me to. Lots of fluffy rice, big portions and great service. One of the best Thai places I've eaten. I always get the Pepper steak. Nice and spicy too!
author: Anne L.

description:
THAI-THENTIC!

Thai food served by waiters decked out in royal blue and gold Thai formal wear in a small palace-like setting with rich golds and burgundys, surrounded by Buddha shrines and paintings; you can't get any more authentic than Thep Phanom. 

On Wednesday, 6.29.11, my friend and I went to Thep Phanom for dinner at 6 PM. As a full-disclosure, we know the owner's daughter at Thep Phanom. 

M E N U
The menu is extensive with many items you will not find at your typical King of Thai or OSHA Restaurants. HH Specials (Mon-Fri 5:30 PM-7:30 PM): $5 appetizers and $2 off all beer, wine and cocktails. All the food is made without MSG which is a HUGE plus in my book because I'm very sensitive to MSG. They also serve brown rice for the health-conscious. 
 
F O O D 
When it comes to ethnic cuisine, I prefer the most authentic and exotic dishes possible, so we asked the owner's daughter to order for us.  

*THEP THONG: Deep Fried Chicken & Corn Balls (HH Special-$5, Regularly $8.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=du0cRl7x3drCaOzqu5Di_A
Hot and crispy, the deep fried bags were filled with savory pieces of ground chicken and sweet tender corn. The Thai chili sauce added a nice sweet heat to the golden bags. 

*KOO GUT: Crispy Fried Yam & Taro w/ Peanut Sauce ($8.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=kIZA0XE_AWNcFf7qsXSLiQ
Thick slices of the yam and taro were fried to crunchy crisp. I have a taro obsession, but I preferred the yam because it had a soft, tender texture with sweetness that went well with the savory, nutty peanut sauce. 

*CRYING TIGER: Spicy Grilled Beef Salad ($14.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=dla3wZb7OTh-V0WntXw5bw
The grilled beef was wonderfully seasoned with prominent hints of garlic and ginger. The char from the grill added a nice smokiness and the vinaigrette gave a nice acidic punch to help balance everything out. 

*THE DANCING LADY: Grilled Jumbo Prawns Stuffed w/ Crab & Serves w/ Spicy Sauce ($14.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=cx7YHZWrFMGTcnuL4wsDeQ
Huge, succulent prawns generously stuffed with tender, sweet crabmeat. It was a simple dish, but the creative presentation, the seafood duo combo, along with the tangy, spicy sauce made for an exotic dish jam-packed with flavor. 

*TAMARIND FISH: Tilapia in Tamarind Sauce ($16.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=LWR6aQZOrkfduyKdOCx-xw
The tilapia was crisp on the outside and tender, flakey on the inside. It was coated with a sticky tamarind sauce which gave a subtle sweet and sour flavor that didn't overpower the delicateness of the fish. 

*PED TOD: Boneless Duck w/ Plum Sauce ($14.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=7WuTdRtg1RPxpV6YZvdOug
Similar to a Chinese roast duck, the skin was ultra crispy; however, it was deep-fried which crisped the duck pieces all around the edges while still maintaining a tenderness inside. The duck was salty and savory with a hint of sweetness. The plum sauce added just the right amount of sweetness with an acidic layer to help cut through some of the richness. 

*BIRDS OF PARADISE: Chef's Famous Quail ($14.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=AXddd23Uk9qIS87-D2vpfw
Perfectly crispy on the outside, the quail still maintained a juicy, tenderness in the inside. I love that the wing was fried to a golden crunchiness which allowed me to devour the wing in it's entirety--crunchy goodness!

*Homemade Cream & Espresso Creme Brulee
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mNBVE3uYArH0xwW3FM5gLA?select=2ppCU4rbOe5eh6gJiuWlZQ
The homemade vanilla ice cream was rich and creamy with a delicate sweetness. The silky smooth espresso crème brulee gave my taste buds a nice jolt with a sweet bitterness which was balanced with a crisp caramelized sugar crust.

S E R V I C E
Friendly and attentive but in a reserved manner.  Food came out relatively quickly and there wasn't much wait time between dishes. Each table was given a water bottle so you can refill your own water glasses which I prefer. 

A M B I A NC E / D É CO R 
Classy, exotic, and quaint; Thep Phanom is perfect for date or a small group dinner. The customary formal Thai clothing the wait staff wears and the ambiance's royal elegance makes for a unique dining experience compared to other Thai restaurants. 

P A R K I N G
Street parking which is more easily found up the block on Fillmore Street. 

Looking for a place to tickle your taste buds? If so, Thep Phanom will provide you with that exotic, sensuous gustatory relief.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: The best Thai tapas in the city with the most gracious and wonderful chef/host Tann.  Open Saturday and Sunday 12:15 both days.  Yelp is wrong! Come in and enjoy the deliciousness.
author: shawn p.

description:
Thep Phanom surprisingly rose to the high expectations often set by a warm childhood memory. The food was a delicious adventure, as was the ambiance. The friendly and prompt service complimented the meal to make for a great dining experience. The only thing that would make it better would be if they still handed out chocolate mints with the check at the end of the meal - specifically the flat little rectangles dressed in green foil. Nevertheless, if you're looking for a great neighborhood Thai experience, I highly recommend Thep Phanom!

We ordered:

Tom Kha Gai (chicken in coconut soup): Warm, milky, with lemon flavor. Great appetizer & big enough serving for 2 hungry people.

Ped Sawan (marinated boneless duck in honey sauce): Sweet, hearty, delicious! Came with rice with the CUTEST presentation - see pic. The handle sticking out the top of the rice belongs to a oar-like paddle, for you to ladle out the tiny carb packets onto your plate. Had leftovers for a yummy lunch the next day!

Kaeng Karee Gai (yellow curry chicken with onion and potato): This dish made us laugh because they really didn't skimp on the potatoes! The potato in this curry came in halves or quarters, not tiny little slices. 

tl;dr - Friendly Service | Gorgeous Ambiance | Interesting Food with Generous Portions
author: Chelsea M.

description: One of the more delicious Thai Spots in San Francisco and a good value too.
author: Yelp Y.

description: Best Happy Hour in San francisco.head chef Yann is the best Real BANGKOK CHEF in town. We live close and come every weekend. Top favorites are Sam KASATR, salad J,Tom kha gai,Birds of Paradise, Crispy Duo,Salt and Pepper Beef Strips,Latb Gai,Crispy Crescent Moon.
author: Christina M.

description:
My wife and I went for the prix fixe menu on a Friday night.  For appetizers we had the golden crescents (Fried pumpkin), tom yum soup, grilled shrimp, and papaya salad.  For appetizers she had the tofu and portabella sautte and I had the coconut seafood trio.

All in all it was very good food; I think the appetizers and the tofu/portabella were the best parts.  My seafood trio was a bit too sweet but that might be just my personal prefernce, I'm not a fan of particularly sweet entrees.

The service was attentive and when we got there around 8 it was not too crowded but that changed by 9.   This is a place to which I'd go back.
author: Alan S.

description: Excellent excellent traditional thai restaurant in the haight and possibly in SF. The service is great and the food is fantastic. They do all the classics right - pad thai, chicken satay, Panama curry, green curry etc. You can definitely taste the fresh ingredients in the fire. Highly highly recommend this place! Excellent find!
author: Kabir S.

description: This place has great good and excellent service! I enjoyed the dancing lady and the fries duck very much! The drinks were great. But the kind service and easy-going waiters made me very happy. I enjoyed the experience very much. It's an intimate unassuming place with kind people. Try it!
author: Kat L.

description: The food was amazing, excellent customer service. I had a great experience here. Everything was delicious. Make sure to order the appetizer Thep Thong.
author: Linh L.

description:
not the great fresh tastes I was hoping for in a Thai restaurant. Maybe it was a poor menu choice...but my nose warned me when we walked in this might not be the best choice..... When the plate arrived the smell actually reminded me of my dog after a long walk in the rain, except I love my dog even when he smells like a wet dog.
Skip this place
sorry- get some fresh herbs and things will get better
author: Shirley W.

description:
Everything we had tasted great & the decor was lots of fun. 
Recommend the Fred pumpkin, quail, panang chicken & thaitanic beef
author: Cindi T.

description: First time ordering here from door dash amazing delievery from them. Me and my husband wanted thai food I yelp this.place got.some.good reviews decided to.order her. We got.the the big prawns, pad thai, vegetables, tamarind fish. All the dishes were very flavorful and tastefully.i would order her again and try their other dishes
author: Hoa T.

description:
Order the salmon basil and lemon grass chicken.
Both dishes were lacking flavor and very plain.
It was $15/per dish.
The best item was a complimentary appetizer.
The service was good.
Would I come back? Probably not.
author: Xavier L.

description: Loved it!  Great food and awesome staff!!!!    Beer specials did not influence this review at all... Promise!
author: G M.

description:
It's very cozy here and I like the ambiance -- much warmer than most of the Thai places in the city. Food wise, it gets a 3-4 depending on what dishes you get. The pad thai isn't great, but the chef specials and seafood dishes are very tasty. They are just very nice as well, even when things get busy. And place is clean. 

Note to G.T. review -- all places are legally required to charge you $.10 for a bag. If they do it, they get to keep the money, if they don't do it, they risk being fined.
author: Kate A.

description:
I am no Thai expert, but I really enjoy dining here.
The ambience is fun, the staff is nice and the food is tasty.
I recommend anything with pumpkins, and the vegetable fried rolls.
It's also a good place where to go in groups and maybe order multiple dishes to share.
author: Amira T.

description: Ordered take out (pad se ew, siamese rolls and the tokfu makur.) All sub-par dishes. The pad se ew was very dry and tofu makur was bland. The people working were very nice though.
author: Sarah M.

description: Enjoyed the food during our semi Xmas (yes review long over due), board and employee gathering for our nonprofit. We had fun, at this place near the heart of Haight. Service was great too. Liked the little sticky rice containers too.
author: Johnson H.

description: I have been coming to this place since it opened. Lovely setting, fabulous owners and wonderful service. Oh, the food? Fresh and delicious. From classics like Pad Thai, Chicken Satay, fresh spring rolls,  to house specials -- the preparation and spices make for a great meal. Very consistent over the years. This restaurant is not as young as the latest places in the lower haight, none, however, are better.
author: Harris T.

description: This used to be a really amazing restaurant - with a nice intimate cozy vibe.   But it wasn't as good as I remembered this last time.  We ordered some happy hour appetizers - the deep fried corn and taro cake was pretty good, the cucumber salad was refreshing, but the larb gai salad and the shrimp salad were salty.  As for the entrees, we ordered the Weeping Willow (minced chicken with eggplant and basil), the prawn and pumpkin curry, and the fried tofu with mixed vegetables.  Everything was okay, but not great, and far too salty.  Given the number of good Thai restaurants to choose from in the city (and the bad parking situation nearby), this is not the first place I'd go back to.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Another yelper called this pad thai "the best pad thai in existence" or something alone those lines, but they must have not eaten much pad thai because ew. Not only was it incredibly bland, but there were no shrimp which is listed in the description. 

Even worse, I got delivery, and yes I live on a busy street, but the delivery driver had the nerve to gripe to me about parking in my neighborhood and the possibility of a ticket AFTER I handed him a 25% tip in cash. Put Fell Street on your list of excommunicated streets if you don't want to deliver to me. 

To sum things up:
What do you expect delivery guy? It's San Francisco.
And what do I expect? Nothing ever again.
author: Natalie R.

description: Love this place!! Menu is extensive and suitable for vegetarians and vegans. Food is fresh and delicious. Service is prompt and friendly. Family owned and operated place. Prices are super reasonable for quality!!! Definitely worth a try - one of my favorite Thai places!!!
author: Maria R.

description: I get that you can't deliver to the whole city, but don't say you're on your way and then cancel at the same time you're supposed to be pulling up. Bad form! Won't be giving my biz to you any longer!
author: Paul T.

description:
Was taken here on a date. 

We arrived about 30 min before it was to close. We where reminded of this but other than that we did not feel rushed. The food was great and the atmosphere was really nice. Very nice traditional decor with american 50's (?) music playing. It was a great mix with out being cheesy. 

Wanted to take  my mom here but they are not open for lunch.
author: Miray V.

description:
a few of us came here after doing the friendshare event nearby.
immediately upon entering, i smelled a sour smell. staff opened up some windows. i wanted to leave, but we were all hungry so hunkered down. 

we ordered pad kee mao, pad thai, fried rice, beef & veggies... to name a few. every item tasted bad.the pad kee mao was super salty, pad thai was really mushy, and fried rice was a runny due to the pineapple. nothing tasted right. very disappointed. 

they have all these awards up in their walls and bathroom... noticed that they stopped earning any after 2009. did their main chef leave?
author: Mimi C.

description: The special thing of this place is they have some Thai ice cream/sorbet that is so tasty and not too sweet. Make sure you order their Thai Iced Tea gelato , Roasted Coconut gelato and passion fruit sorbet. They are all natural made. We love having a dinner party there.
author: Funn F.

description: This restaurant has the best Thai food in the Bay Area and has many years of awards to prove it. I live across the city and drive here to get take out because the food is so exceptional. I highly recommend the green curry, chefs famous basil mushroom and salad J, but everything is delicious. Definitely worth it if you can find parking.
author: Kristin H.

description: I have ordered from this restaurant on a few other occasions always seemed to some issues . Tonight ensured I will never again. I placed a delivery order and received a email confirmation of the order and my credit card was charged for the full amount. 30 mins after the estimated delivery time I call the restaurant to see what is the status of my order. After speaking to several incompetent staff members who can't seem to understand I am trying to find where my order  is , who keep asking me if I want to place a order I find out they charged me but did not process my order.  If I wanted my food I would have to wait at least another hour to receive it. Had to call the ordering service to get my refund as they refused to. Plenty of other thai restaurants in the city that are not out to con their customers.
author: Marie J.

description:
Delicious!! Amongst the top Thai food I have ever had.  And well priced!
Pineapple fried rice!! 
Thanks thep!!!
author: Jerry S.

description:
Went out to dinner here with my roommate on a Thursday night. I thought the service was very good, atmosphere was very nice, and the wine list is surprisingly good. 

I ordered the beef munamun (probably mispelled that) curry and my roommate got his usual grilled beef (the dish has a name, I'm just blanking). 

I don't recommend the curry I ordered, I thought the sauce was off in flavor and too thick, but I'm fairly certain I just ordered the wrong thing. Everything else coming to the tables around us looked amazing. Mine just looked...blah. The sticky rice was great though!

As I'm typing this I realize that I probably should make another visit and try something else.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Great thai food....have not been here in 20 years. Place was packed and parking is pure hell...but the food is fresh, fragrant and flavorful.

Nice tofu pad thai, fried calamari(crispy and spicy), nice spicy shrimp dish. And the folks that work here are really great. Glad I came back.

thank you!
author: David G.

description:
So great to come back after a few years. As good as ever! #yum #classic #thai 
To expand- I've been coming here for 15+ years. I've never had them as take out, always dining in. I've had numerous phenomenal meals.. Quality meat- when I don't go veggie, excellent spices and favors- the hottest Thai I've had, when I asked for "spicy". Consistently good service and food. Plan for arriving early or expect a wait; it's an intimate space. Five stars!
author: Ronda I.

description:
I've been here too many times to list.  The food is consistently good and fresh.  They have remodeled and the new dining room is not as crowded and provides a nice, romantic ambiance.

We discovered they have a great Happy Hour menu with significantly lower prices on many items.
author: S E.

description: Delicious food and attentive service.  The food is presented beautifully, too.  I tried this place for the first time with friends last week, and was very happy with everything we ordered.
author: Eden H.

description:
My coworkers brought me here for a nice farewell dinner and the service and food did not disappoint! Located between Duboce triangle and Haight my coworkers and I arrived during the restaurant's happy hour. We noticed that the happy hour appetizer portions were smaller but perfect for those who just want to nibble on something with their drinks. The waiters were friendly and attentive and the drinks were HUGE! I had a Mai Tai and one of my coworker's ordered a Singha.

We ordered the following items family style:

Spicy Green Papaya Salad 
Chicken & Shrimp Pad Thai
Yellow Curry Chicken & Potatoes
Basil Chicken
Sticky Rice
 
All the dishes were delicious, except the Yellow Curry Chicken was a bit too salty for my taste, and the portions served were large enough that I was able to take a doggy bag home.

Thep Phanom has been around for almost 30 years now. I definitely recommend this place if you are looking for some good thai food and a real SF dining experience.
author: Amy S.

description:
I think it must be different chefs with different skills that work here - if you look at the reviews, they are either a 1 or 4/5 stars (binodal distribution).  last time, the food was really good.  this time, the pad thai was undercooked, dry, flavorless, and the shrimp looked wrong.  the chicken coconut soup was inedible and now rests in the disposal. (it was take out)

CAN SOMEONE FROM THE RESTAURANT PLEASE PAY ATTENTION AND FIRE THE  BAD CHEF AND HIRE A GOOD ONE?
author: reza n.

description:
I was determined to have some Thai food tonight, but wasn't going to venture too far out.  It seemed that this spot may be one of the better restaurants in the area, but I was very mistaken.

The siamese rolls were burnt, oily, and the filling was remarkably bland.  The sauce it comes with is intensely syrupy sweet and had a strange aftertaste.  Very underwhelming.

The tom yum soup with shrimp had a nice broth, but had some glaring flaws.  The prawns were absolutely butchered, sliced way too far open to remove the vein, and random bits and pieces hanging on for dear life.  My wife commented that the prawns looked like they had elephantiasis.  The prawns were also rubbery (massively overcooked).  There were raw pieces of galangal in the soup, which are inedible and should not be served, and then raw bell pepper and white onion.  I know some people like raw bell peppers, but the completely uncooked onion in the soup didn't make any sense and just overpowers. 

The pad thai suffered the same prawn issue, being mutilated and overcooked (but not as bad).  The noodles were overcooked and all stuck together in a big lump.  Barely any tofu, peanuts or bean sprouts, and the whole dish was just one note and very salty.  

Based on what I ate, the food here is not good or well executed.  I do not recommend eating here.
author: Nathan B.

description: We got takeout and the pumpkin curry was fantastic. I will definitely try it again.
author: Darren F.

description: I really love this place. It has taken me a little while to find my favorite Thai delivery and Thep Phanom is it! I can't say enough about the green curry - super yummy!
author: Emily P.

description: This place is phenomenal. From start to finish. Service et food. Had a restaurant.com coupon otherwise i would never have heard of this place! Will definitely return as a regular. Thank you for a great meal! Also child-friendly! :)
author: s t.

description:
A good place to go when you are sick and tired of the usual below $10/person Thai Restaurants.  The quality of vegetables and meat used here is noticeably better than those cheaper alternatives.  Expect to pay 20-30% more; however, don't mistaken this place as an upscale restaurant at $15-$20/person price point.  While they have table cloth, it is covered by a glass tabletop.  Interior is interesting, but not plush.  Tables are close together and it could get laud.  Staff was Thai, so perhaps food is really authentic as they claim on the sign outside.  Note that I've been to Thailand multiple times, but I cannot judge authenticity of Thai food.  All I know is that the food here was very good.     

Only problem with this place is that I can never remember the restaurant's name.
author: トモ T.

description: The food I got was good (I believe I got the Titanic Beef because what a great name), but make sure if you're ordering takeout, you order rice too! My dish didn't come with rice as a default which I only figured out after I had gone home. Sort of a bummer. I'd go back, though, to try more things!
author: M.E. F.

description: This Thai Restaurant is the best in the SF and maybe even in the Bay area bar none!. They have every day specials that they recommend base on what you are craving. I would recommend start off with the beef salad and pair it with white wine. I also love the Pad Thai, Shrimp Fried rice, and the crispy beef (its an appetizer). Try it and guarantee that you will not walk away disappointed from your dining experience!!!
author: Armand B.

description: Titanic Beef, Basil Basil Shrimp - it's all good, all fresh. Awesome Thai food, lovely staff.  Used to be more crowded, much easier to get in now.
author: Tom D.

description: BLAND.  There are a lot of good Thai places in SF, this in not one of them.  The food is downright lousy and lacks flavor of any kind,  I've eaten there a  hand ful of times, and will not return.
author: Samuel Y.

description: We had an awesome Thai meal that was Michelin recommended for less then fifty bucks. The lemon grass chicken salad was phenomenal. Fantastic happy hour fro 5:30 to 7:00. I've been to Thailand a few times this place beats anywhere I ate over there.
author: Kristopher U.

description: I live around the corner from here, and this has become my go-to Thai place.  For the price (~$10/dish, cheaper appetizers during happy hour), I think the food is very good.  As a vegetarian, I like the range of options, particularly the Thaitanic tofu and the Pad See Ew.  The atmosphere is really laid-back and the decorations are nice.  Would definitely recommend this place!
author: Sophie S.

description:
Over the weekend, I had a really special experience at a restaurant new to us.  It's called Thep Phanom (http://thepphanom.com/Thepphanom/Home.html).  Wow!!!  Was it ever excellent.  Easily the best Thai cuisine in years.  We had their stuffed chicken wings for an appetizer.  Spectacular.  Then we had their Yum Nua (or beef salad).  Spectacular.  I had the red curry duck---best I have ever had plus the fact that the portion was huge. A friend had the lemon grass chicken with veggies...large portion.  Spectacular.  Our hosts had sautéed minced chicken and eggplant and sautéed chicken with Thai basil.  

It turns out I thought I knew all the really great Thai restaurants in San Francisco.  Maybe now I do.  It turns out that Thep Phanom has actually been around for years.  No idea why I hadn't heard about it.  It's address is 400 Waller Street at the corner of Waller and Fillmore.  Enjoy!!!
author: Gary R.

description: Thep Phanom is a very solid 3 star Thai restaurant in my book.  For an appetizer, I tried the Thep Thong.  This dish was completely awesome, and I highly recommend it.  It's chicken and corn made into a pouch-like form and deep fried like a spring roll and served with dipping sauces.  For dinner I had the pad thai which was not bad at all.  It came with 3 large sized prawns, egg, & tofu.  It was a little bit dry for my taste, but it did hit the spot for my pad thai craving.  For drinks, I'd definitely recommend the lychee mojito if you're a fan of lychee.  It's very sweet, but very tasty.
author: Zach S.

description: Ordered delivery.  Several ingredients were missing from what the menu described upon delivery.  There was a billing error, which I was disputing with the delivery service and was being resolved by the delivery service.  The restaurant called me over 26 times in the course of 4 hours leaving harassing voicemails - they went so far as to have the delivery guy follow a neighbor in to my secured building so he could pound on my door the next night.
author: Matt W.

description:
I recently visited here with a girlfriend because there was an hour and a half wait at our usual spot.  I looked it up on yelp and saw 3.5 stars and we were about to turn around, but there was no way I was waiting an hour and a half when I was this starving.

We were seated right away (party of 2) and the restaurant was full, but not packed.  The decor set a good atmosphere, and the settings made the place feel upscale. I liked that the rice came in the little baskets, but also appreciated the plastic lining (I would get nervous that the basket wouldn't really ever be clean without it). Much better than bringing it in a regular bowl like every other place. The service was great - checking in enough, but not too much.  It was that seamless "I'm there when you need me, but not disrupting your evening" kind of manner. One star for nice ambience and one star for service.

I have a food allergy, and the staff was very knowledgeable about it and was able to recommend dishes or alterations to dishes to accommodate me.  That, I love.  I get so nervous when the staff has no clue and you can tell they are guessing. When our server wasn't sure, he double-checked with the chef and was happy to do so. One star alone for just setting me at ease.

Then to the food... We tried four dishes: Tofu Sate, Fresh spring rolls, Salad (I am blanking on which one, but it also had tofu) and the tofu/pumpkin curry. The spring rolls were great and had a nice twist with added mushrooms.  I didn't get to try my friends salad (it had soy sauce, part of my allergy) but she said it was good.  The curry was really tasty, and it's hard to go wrong with pumpkin.  The presentation really was great and added to the upscale feel. However, the dishes really weren't pricey (so no upscale bill!). I think our total came to ~$50.  That's a good meal - $25 per person, with so much food.  No complaints with the food - so one more star. 

I'm glad we took a chance even though it was only 3.5 stars on yelp, because this place is really 4 stars.  We had a very pleasant experience, good service, good food - this may be a new addition into our "regular" rotation.
author: Liz M.

description:
Past Friday I again stopped  to eat here. Just a fab place for thai. Kind staff, great food.
Try prawns with fried portabello mushrooms.
Fifth  time visit
author: Mike L.

description:
The food was fine. I've given this place two tries and have been let down both times. We're pretty reasonable and forgiving but when BOTH experiences fail...it's time to rethink where we get our thai food. 

To name a few of the disappointments. 

1) We were told our food would be to our doorstep in 30 minutes. It took a little over 1 hour and we live a block away. To be fair, the weather hasn't been great, but still...a block away? I could walk there in 5 minutes, walking slowly... 

2) We asked for super spicy food (thai hot) and we got mild. I could hardly see any thai chili peppers in my dish. I'm not sure they tried. 

3) We got the +$2 prawn addition to one of our dishes. We got 2 small shrimp thrown into the dish...2...I might have been happy with 3.

That's the last time we'll be ordering from this place.
author: Sara M.

description: My favorite Thai in the city! Great pre-fix and great staff. Best tom ka gai I've ever had, makes me so happy on a cold foggy night. It's also a great date spot. Go eat and leave happy and satisfied. It is a lil pricey compared to other Thai food, the pre-fix is a great deal though, and they have a happy hour! Grab a cocktail and some great dishes! It'll be worth it! I recommend the dancing lady, any of the curries, the bikini shrimp salad, and titanic tofu.
author: Meesh S.

description:
*10 buck ton of noodles and so much more*
#greatportions
#padseeawesome

After a late afternoon of beer tasting we ventured over to this gem in lower Haight. First thing we noticed was the dress code. These servers had awesome pants on that I think they should sell. Big fluffy Aladdin like pants in bright Ted and purples. That along was star worthy

A fun, international beer selection, cozy environment, and soft yellow ambient lighting made it quite a fun spot. The crowd was coming in shortly after we arrived

They have a drink called the Bangkatini... Amazing, was like emptying a juice box and adding booze...a super high class juice box

We were plain and decided to order pad Thais and pad see ew as I was craving noodles.

My goodness, a fat heaping portion of noodles and fresh vegetables amazed me. The noodles were not laden with grease but had amazing flavor in each bite. I didn't even need chili sauce to compliment it it was so good.

We threw the leftovers in a doggy box but I am sure to come back to try some more
author: Kevin T.

description:
Waiters in authentic Thai dress are the real deal at this unassuming Haight restaurant.  We experienced a slight language barrier on first contact.  But, any discomfort from that, and the tightly packed tables, disappeared when the food arrived.

I opted for the $19.95 prix fixe menu.  While all the food was solidly good, the star of the meal was the appetizer -- long, curved, thick strips of fried pumpkin served with peanut sauce that elicted oohs and aahs from the table.  The texture and taste make this great comfort food.  The tom kom gai soup, with chicken and lemongrass, was tasty but pretty standard.  My entree of tamarind pork was tender and accompanied by a sweet tamarind sauce that was too sweet for my taste.  The freshness of ingredients was noticeable in all the food.

Thep Phanom provided great value in a city where that can be hard to find, especially if you're not a local.
author: Will T.

description:
Im not sure why the reviews are just so-so.  I enjoyed my meal quite a bit.  this was our return to the US dinner with my family and we had a few drinks (alcoholic and non alcoholic to start).  Beers, which I was told were great and thai hot tea, which was delicious and continally refilled.  We started with the tom yum soup, that was not so great.  We ordered the 
a) Basil chicken
b) Red curry with chicken
c) Pad Thai
d) brown rice, which I LOVED
All the dishes were tasty and flavorful

Dessert- flaming banana with caramel goodness.  ooh the memory!  and there were other fruits on it as well!
Service was sometimes spotty but when we asked for something we got it right away.

Next time in the Lower haight, I will be back!
author: Namita A.

description: Right down the street from my sister's apartment. Real neighborhood gem! All of what we ordered (see photos) were delicious and our party of 4 demolished every last bite.
author: Kathy L.

description: Great thai food! I placed a large delivery order for an event at my home. They were very professional; called to confirm the order (which I made using Eat24, here on Yelp). Very accommodating for special requirements/requests and the order was right on time. The food was great! Looking forward to going to the actual restaurant in the future!
author: Tanya S.

description:
Always wondered about this dark Thai restaurant on the corner.  We finally tried it and had decent but totally overpriced Thai food.  If I'm going to pay over $10 for a Thai plate it better be amazing. 

The yellow curry was good.  I do recommend if you decided to enter the place.

Service was fine, environment is nice and romantic.  Food needs to be cheaper.
author: Chad S.

description: Sooo sad to report the steep deline in quality.  Even with the 2 course menu including rice for $20/person, we won't return.  There was a long gap, over 30 mins between courses AND they forgot 1 person's (out of 4) meal.  The lag was also lame bc 3 (out of 4) ordered the same main dish (I know that's generally lame but it was the only choice that appealed to us).  The food was ok but not worth the price, wait & parking challenge.
author: Kim S.

description:
It's a cute place with a nice vibe, much better looking than your regular neighborhood Thai joint. I wanted more authentic flavors to come through, but all our dishes (duck larb, pumpkin tofu curry, pad see ew, and "Thaitanic" beef) mainly tasted of salt. Worse, the saltiness tasted like it came from either the granular salt or soy sauce, rather than a good fish sauce and/or shrimp paste.

Points for offering sticky rice, minus for sticking it in a plastic bag inside the woven rice container. If cleaning the weave is a pain, just put the sticky rice in a bowl -- the plastic is tacky and detracts from the experience.
author: Lauren G.

description: I really enjoy eating here. The food is delicious, the service is warm and welcoming, and the ambiance is intimate.  I always order the Tom Kha Gai - it bursts with layers of flavor!  I don't live in this neighborhood, so it's definitely a destination place for me.
author: Jennifer B.

description: I love going here, the atmosphere inside is cozy and the decorations are nice. Good pad see ew and I love the pineapple fried rice. They have a good menu for vegetarians, i eat meat but a lot of my friends are vegetarians, so it's a good place for both.
author: Kalani M.

description: This place was great 20 years ago.  Now it's mediocre.  My papaya salad was bland.  My eggplant and tofu dish was just okay.
author: Jane L.

description: 1 hour 45 minute delivery time. My order came only half full in the container. WTF. So hungry by now I'm eating the napkins they delivered.
author: Roy B.

description: Food was terribly greasy and chicken tasted horrible. Threw it out.
author: Tim O.

description:
Had dinner here with 3 friends late Saturday night. The waitstaff was quick and accommodating to get us a table as it was packed from the regular dinner hour. That was about the high point of the service we received. 

The food was bland and trendy presentation was clearly the focus over flavor. We asked the waiter for recommendations and he offered nothing more than quickly directing us to the two most expensive items on the menu. 

Appetizer offering was all fried and the soups do not offer individual portions. They also charge $2 for a bowl of rice to eat with meals that are made to be eaten with rice. How generous. 

Also, I've never been to a restaurant where 18% gratuity is automatically added to a party of 4 followed by the sales tax being added last. Essentially we were charged 3% more on tip and then taxed on the full amount so the restaurant is pocketing extra tax money.  

And never have I been charged a fee to have the bill split evenly four ways on credit card. Maybe it's a west coast thing (this is my first time in Cali)?

They get two stars for being clean, the brief moment of accommodation, and restaurant ambiance.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Came here with a friend tonight and although the food is good, I am still partial to my other favorite Thai restaurant in the Tenderloin.    

Some things that I liked:
-Duck Larb
-Dessert selection - much broader than most Thai restaurants
-Hot drink selection - included COFFEE and HOT TEA
-It was CLEAN (The inspection score=100%)
-The service was pleasant.
-The menu had a lot of options.

I also ordered the Tom Kha Gai, which was ok.

Nothing extraordinary, but a good experience.  Yet, the cost is what surprised me.

1 order of soup, 1 order of fried taro/yam (4 sticks), 1 order of duck larb, 1 order of bbq pork, 2 orders of rice (small portions), 3 orders of non-alcoholic drinks (1 coke, 1 small thai ice tea, 1 hot tea)  and the bill w/tax (w/o tip)=$67.  

EEK.  

The portion sizes are smaller than some other restaurants.  It isn't such a big deal for me, as I tend to eat smaller meals anyways.  The bowl of soup was large and there was leftovers (which I think that I left at the restaurant *oops*)
author: Hiromi N.

description: Uninspired. I think that about sums it up. If you're looking for food, it's certainly that. Just don't be expecting that other special element: taste. Oh, taste--how I missed you! We ordered the lemon grass chicken and the pad Thai, and neither mustered taste. How can you make tasteless pad Thai? It's almost an accomplishment. Almost. Expect slow service, and some exotic music while you wait.
author: Stuart S.

description: I ate here a while back, but the food here was quite good and their happy hour deals are pretty great. We got a variety of dishes, none of which disappointed. I also enjoyed their cocktails, though they are very sweet and girly. Sadly, I had to knock a star off for a bug on one of our dishes. They brought us a new one, but definitely kinda killed the appetite.
author: Aleyna S.

description: One of thee best Thai restaurants in SF by far.  If you have ever been to Thailand you would know that this place is as close to authentic you can get in the bay.  Try the pineapple fried rice and eggplant beef!!
author: Patrick C.

description: After a long day of traveling I called in an order for delivery.   They told me no problem it would be there in 30 minutes.   It never showed, no call or anything.  I tried to call them and their line was busy every time I tried for the next hour.  Screw these losers!
author: King O.

description:
I'd heard how amazing this place is from a number of people.

But.

I was not bowled over.

Not knocked off my feet.

In fact I was more knocked over by the big bill at the end of an OK meal.

I'd stopped in here, after a long day. 

I called my friend to meet me.

Reluctantly he met me, claiming he had already eaten.

So we split a simple fried tofu appetizer, and I ordered the basil fried portabella mushroom entree with rice.

He sampled some of the entree, but barely touched it. I found it tasty, and enjoyed the crispy portabella, but have had had better thai food elsewhere.

I was the only one who really ate and the total came to 26 dollars.

I'm sure the rest of the menu is probably pretty good, but I don't think Thep Phanom's food is worth their prices.

I can buy a whole week's worth of amazing Love N Haight sandwiches for about 26 dollars. 

Or enjoy a dinner for two for that price - at Thai Place.
author: Jessica T.

description: We loved the venue and the food... but the service was VERY slow. We'll give them one more shot...
author: Sean B.

description:
Formerly my favorite Thai restaurant.

Then I discovered Marnee Thai and just like that, things were over for me and Thep Phanom. But I can't say it was only Marnee that did it. The increasing prices, combined with the decreasing quality is what lead me to stray in the first place. I'm loyal, but when I feel done wrong, I'm not the type to just lie there and take it, ya know?

Now, though Thep Phanom is just blocks from me, I take the N-Judah  to my new favorite Thai restaurant where I get a consistently better meal at just over half the cost of what dinner at Thep Phanom would set me back.

Thep Phanom, if you want me back, get your act together. There are too many Thai restaurants in this town for you to be charging those prices for that food. Ya heard?

UPDATE:
I returned to Thep to see if my harsh words had had any effect. I was pleased with my meal. Not pleased enough to change from three stars to four, just yet, but I will return again to see if that might be warranted.
author: Miriam W.

description: I've tried a few other places for Thai delivery and this is by far the best. Thom Kha  soup was spicy and tangy, perfectly seasoned.  My son loved the chicken satay and the panang was well received by the husband. They will be my go to!
author: J H.

description:
This is pretty good Thai, but the taste of the food is far from earth shattering. Dan raved about this place, but warned us that the old timers have complained this place has gone downhill. 

We started with the Papaya Salad. It was gorgeously presented, but it was just shredded papaya. The Tom Yum Soup followed and came family sized, and each of us ended up with roughly 2 bowls. The taste was a bit bland. 

For the main dish, we had the Titanic Beef, which was by far the best tasting, but most plain looking dish of the night. Then came the Tamarind Fish, which was quite good, but not particularly noteworthy. All in all, the food is barely hanging on to their 3 stars, but they get a little firmer footing for the gorgeous presentation and wonderful ambiance.

It's a fun place to go, but not sure I'd make it a destination.
author: Charlie L.

description:
Pretty good Thai food in a cute converted Victorian in the Lower Haight. Good enough to warrant it being written up as Michael Bauer's favorite Thai restaurant in the Bay Area for 5 years? I think not.

Still, really good food and some inventive dishes.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
got there early with a friend on a saturday night at around 5pm.  In all honesty, we just wanted to get out of the rain.  despite the torrential downpour, they insisted we should come back in 30 minutes when the restaurant officially opened, so we went up the street to the nearest walgreens to read magazines while we waited.  came back 30 minutes later and they sat us right next to the window to watch the lighting from inside.  

the interior was quite spacious and dimly lit, perfect for a date.  we shared the pad thai, yellow curry, thai ice teas, and two servings of rice.  It was the perfect amount for two average sized girls, even though initially, it didn't look like much.  

everything was delicious.  they put crushed iced in the thai iced teas, which made them infinitely better for some reason.  And the food was not spicy at all.  Strangest part of the whole dining experience was the music they were playing: acoustic jazzy/lounge-y versions of old indie rock hits. just imagine a pink martini cover of Creep by Radiohead...uh alright.  lol
author: Tracy N.

description:
I've eaten here twice now. It's a block away from my apartment in the Lower Haight and I love having it in the neighborhood. From the outside it doesn't look like much, but it's one of the best Thai restaurants I've been to. 

Here are the must haves:
-Punmpkin and shrip red curry (FANTASTIC!)
-The fried fish with taro and tamarind reduction (they debone it too)
-Thai iced tea (if you like it, it's great here)

If you have some non-adventerous dinners that like the basics. The pad see eww is moist and not to sweet. 

The tom kai goong (lemon grass soup with shrip) isn't spicy enough. You might need to add some of your own chili. But some Thai friends said the intensity of the lemon grass flavor is right on. 

Nice automsphere and delicous thai food at the right price.
author: Philip H.

description:
What a disappointment! 

We hadn't eaten here in years, but it was always one of our favorites. We went Saturday night. The service was fine, the atmosphere OK (except for the canned muzak), but the food was mediocre at best. We had about 8 dishes all told ( a large party) so were able to sample the offerings. The pad Thai was fine, but the steak dish was way overdone -- charred, actually, the chicken dish lacked any flavor at all; some of the noodle dishes were greasy.  A pork dish was actually the only really flavorful dish. Thankfully, there are many other Thai places in the city.
author: Mark P.

description:
I've found my SF Thai place. =) I'd go back any time. Amazing. Best Thai I've had.

Beautiful service, food and interior ambiance. This place definitely has it all.

I had the yellow curry which came with chicken and the standard onion/potato combo and I opted for brown rice (Which they have, yay). Also had a fish appetizer, unsure of name and one of the noodle dishes, unsure of name. Obviously I can only remember yellow curry but the other two were amazing. 

The fish came out as a whole fish (kinda cool to see) with the interior cut out into bit sized pieces, there were also peanuts and mangos adorning the plate. Yummmmm.

The noodle dish had thick cut noodles, vegetables, and chicken. It was full of garlic tastiness. 

Go here now.
author: Kendra S.

description:
The food here is just like the service. Novice and ignorant. It should be good, it's got all the right parts, but it fails at life. 

Quick review: bland, overpriced, bad service. If ur boss reccomends this place, kick him the the balls because he just fucked you.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
This is Thai food for white people, which is to say it sucks. Thailand cuisine is known for being spicy, and spicy in the best way. Thep Phanom's cuisine lacks that in its entirety.

The ambiance is very nice--cloth napkins, decent low-key music, decent lighting--but it's *really* expensive for not having good food or the most amazing menu selections. If you didn't want a fried appetizer that's not meat on a stick, btw, you can't get it four days out of the week. Friday through Sunday are when you can get the fresh wraps.

They either need to cook their food properly or lower their price, both to get five stars.

Save your money for one of the hundreds of other Thai restaurants in San Francisco and avoid this place.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Value - 3.6
Food - 3.6
Service - 3.75
Ambience - 3.5
Overall -
author: aaron h.

description:
Most delicious Thai food I've ever had, and I've had a lot.

Also, great outfits on the waitstaff.
author: Jason K.

description:
I have frequented this place a few times over the years. Typically it is decent and once and awhile its really good. Last night it really sucked!

We ordered 2 appetizers ( fried yam and chicken wings) and 2 dinners ( Yellow Curry Chicken and Pad Thai)

The fried yam was ok. The chicken wings were incredibly greasy and exceptionally small. The Pad Thai was salty and the Yellow Curry Chicken was just ok. The best part was the brown rice.

The food lacked the spice I would hope to find in a quality Thai place. The total bill including two non-alcoholic drinks came out to about $50. I felt kind of ripped off and wished we stayed in.

The service and ambiance was nice.
author: Meia M.

description:
I love this place; nice ambiance, and the food is great.

The Crispy Tofu was really amazing (very flavorful and crispy!), and even though I'm not a vegetarian I'm definitely tempted to order this in the future. Pad Thai was also great. The Red Shrimp curry was excellent (one of my favorite dishes here).  Lemon Grass chicken could have had a bit more pizazz.

Cons: I think they've raised their prices, which I find disappointing because you really can find great Thai here for a reasonable price (for example, Manora Thai is excellent and cheap). Also, the rice servings were very small (and way smaller than it's been in the past), so overall, I guess I'm disappointing that you'll find less value here than you have in the past.  

Another con: for their anniversary, they are serving one free glass of wine or soju with your meal this month. Well, the wine and soju is, as one would expect, probably the cheapest possible. The soju tasted more like Gilby's vodka. When booze is that bad (crappy booze at a frat party is one thing, quite another with your dinner), I'd rather just not have it at all because it in no way enhances the food (it's bad when you're eating the food just to wash down the taste of gross booze).
author: Jessica L.

description:
3.5 stars rounded down.

Not the greatest Thai place I've been to, but at 3 blocks away from our new apt at 9pm, we were hungry and it served its purpose.

We both ordered off the prix fixe menu, which is a very good deal if you have a "nice meal" in mind.  As in, nice presentation, interesting flavors, and small portions.  Interesting flavors I welcome any time, but the other two characteristics I wouldn't associate with my go-to neighborhood Thai joint.

The food itself was tasty.  I've been going back and forth (in the course of this review) trying to decide between rounding Thep Phanom up or down from 3.5 stars.  So I present you with the facts:
1. The food tasted very good
2. I was expecting less fancy, more filling dishes
3. My thai iced tea came in a small aluminum cup (adorable) filled with crushed ice (ripoff) with just a few sips of beverage

Service was iffy.  There were three waitstaff to serve about 5-7 occupied tables.  It took us til the third guy to actually get some water.  With the second course.  It became almost a joke...how funny would it be if we asked every single waiter and went through all three courses without ever getting any water?  Almost a joke...that wouldn't be funny.

And it looks like we're ending up rounding down.
author: Cathy Y.

description: The appetizers were my favorite part... fried pumpkin, spring rolls, and chicken satay.  I really liked the wine we ordered... it was red but i don't know what it was called.
author: Julie B.

description:
A very handsome boy brought me here several weeks ago and while it wasn't a Blow-You-Socks-Off experience (the meal, I meant), I can see how some people have a penchant for this establishment. It's cute, has that neighborhood-gem feel and the food isn't bad (albeit a bit on a pricier side, IMO). 

He ordered the Pad See Yew noodles (did I spell that correctly?) and the waitress informed us shortly after taking our order that they were out of the specific type of noodle for that dish so we substituted the carbs using some shorter variant. He had a better experience with this dish the last time he visited this haunt so this didn't quite live up to expectations, I suspect. 

I ordered some 3 course meal with Bangkok chicken wings (something was unexpected about this appetizer but I can't recall what was 'off'), Tom Yum Goong soup and Red Curry w/ Pumpkin & Prawns. The soup was tasty but lukewarm and my curry didn't arrive for the first ~25+mins of our meal. We inquired about it at some point and it turns out the staff had completely forgotten about it :(. 

Had the soup been hotter, the noodles the right type, our dishes arriving on time, and had the boy not shown me the next day how easy was to make penang curry by whipping us up a batch, I might be compelled to give this place 4 stars.
author: Ida C.

description: You know it's good when the pineapple fried rice is served in an actual friggin' pineapple. I had the Thaitanic beef dish which was out of this world. Pumpkin and tofu with peanut sauce apps were great too. The only disappointment was the tapioca pudding, which was served warm and with lots of corn in it (?).
author: John S.

description:
We've had so many nice meals here and I'm constantly surprised by the creativity of their dishes.  We plan on going back many times!
-g
author: Greg B.

description:
So here's an update. I guess I got my wish and they read my review, because I got a private message and this is what it said;

"YEAH. I read your message... and i think it's rediculous! THEY have many african american friends. For you to say stuff like that it's very FUCKING RETARDED. The other people who got seats in front of you guys probably made reservations! THEY do not treat their customers like that. Grow the fuck up. Maybe your the one who's racist to begin with LOL. DUMB IDIOT." 

Author of the quote above: Ms. Bartender G

Yea, how bout not being petty Thep Phanom Thai, and just have better service that does not prioritized by skin color.
author: arlene r.

description:
Only 2 noodle dishes? I was disappointed. But then my boyfriend ordered the Pad Thai and it was great. I love that they serve it with metal tongs so you don't have to awkwardly scoop it off your plate with a fork. Very efficient, me likey! 

I ordered the tilapia with green curry sauce and coconut milk (Pra-In Long Srong). It was huge! For $15 you get a bunch of very tasty fillets that are lightly breaded and fried. It also came served on the whole fish that had been scraped out - awesome plating.

Overall, this place is a yummy and not too expensive (but not "cheap thai food"). On a Wednesday night at 7:45pm, it was fairly crowded, which I take to be a good sign. I just wish they had more noodle choices.

P.S. A+ brown rice.
author: Hannah L.

description:
I don't know why people make such a fuss over this restaurant. First of all, it's Thai food for white people. Second, they put way too much sugar in the food trying to compensate for ingredients that they can't get here. Third, the service is mediocre. 

I have been here throughout the years and recently went again because it was 9pm and they were open. The restaurant was half empty because of the late hour but we still had to wait over a half hour to get two dishes. What? Where am I? This isn't' Michael Minna. It's Thai food. When it finally arrives, I'm happy because I'm hungry but after digging in, I'm disappointed because this isn't my Thailand's Thai food. It's some watered down version for white people (which I am). Having been numerous times to Thailand, I want authentic Thai food. For that you need Ozone or Be my Guest.
author: Fiona F.
