description: Pretty amazing, we lived next door for 6 years and miss it all of the time!  Many folks that visited us in SF were introduced to this place and still talk about it years later.  Definately worth a visit.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This was the go to Thai restaurant for years ( in the 90's)  with our crowd,along with  Khan Toke Thai House for authentic first rate traditional Thai. They hit their high marks then when cuisine was not at the level of today. Not a lot has changed here, the quality is still high despite some of the reviews I saw below , but it's not as fresh or exciting as i remember. 
They have  great deal going  from 5:30 - 7 weekdays with $ 5 appetizers. The wait staff still dresses in snazzy blue and gold and are very attentive and friendly if a bit shy.
Apps; Fried fish cakes, calamari, and vegetarian rolls not completely traditional but very good with a Singha, Thai  beer. 
Chicken in spicy soup is killer with lemon grass and coconut  milk or the sour and spicy version. Weeping Lady : minced chicken with eggplant  was mushy in the mouth , not real appetizing. We had  the green curry chicken and red curry duck all good and flavorful. Pad Thai, of course, they do a real respectable version of this essential dish.
We also had  Param beef which I love with the peanut sauce. 
Finished off the meal with a deep fried banana and ice cream mmm. 

The room is nicely appointed and ambiance fairly nice, all except the TV behind the bar which the staff seems to watch ,( yeah guys lose the TV)  and I would suggest they change the muzak in the place,  versions of familiar hit songs sung by very unfamiliar , wannabe singers. This starts out humorous then becomes annoying ,and after a few beers is funny again...
author: Aaron Z.

description:
This is one of my favorite Thai Restaurant in the city just for the very fact that they have all you can drink Thai Iced Tea.

I'm a creature of comfort when it comes to eating so I tend to go for what I know especially when it's a new restaurant for me.  When I went here for the 1st time, I couldn't resist the urge to try The Dancing Lady...boy I wasn't disappointed.  Very tasty it's just too bad they only give you 4.

The prices aren't bad although I tend to eat Thai food a lot so going here is an extra treat because it is a bit more expensive than other Thai restaurants I frequent.

I love the way they present the food and the ambiance is a big bonus.
author: Lyra K.

description:
I'm on the fence about this one.  I had one really good dish and one okay dish.  But even the okay dish was a big step above Osha Thai.  My best advice is to stick with the specialities and do not order the curries.  The curries are good but not outstanding (plus it's good to get out of that chicken green curry rut).  Their other non-curry dishes though are excellent .  I love the spiciness and depth of flavor.  

Stuffed chicken wings - stuffed with glass noodles then deep fried.  And without any bones in it.  How do they do it?

Weeping Lady (love the cheesy names) - minced chicken with eggplant and fried basil.  Fried basil was done really well.  Crispy and flavorful and a real part of the dish instead of just an herb thrown in that you have to spit out because it's too overpowering.

Prices for dishes are between $10-$15.  The two of us ordered a starter and two dishes and it was waaay too much food.
author: Jean K.

description: Love Thep long, long time.  Hate the elevator music.  I would much prefer traditional Thai music or Thai opera.  Those I heart Thep Phemon T-shirts make me feel like I am Chucky Cheese. Go back to the old way of doing business and the customers will come back.  Tan & Pat are a great duo and put out some of the best Thai food in the world, and I have been to Thailand!
author: Kurt H.

description:
It's a small restaurant with a nicer decor than most Thai restaurants.  The food and the service are also above average.  Of course, it's also slightly more expensive with entrees in the $10-16 range.  

We had Calamari salad, the Dancing Ladies (Stuffed Prawns on skewers) and beef with string beans.  The presentation is much nicer than most Thai restaurant and everything was flavorful.  The food is spicier and more authentic at Lers Ros and Tawan.  However, if I have friends in town that want good Thai food, presentation and ambience, this would be my choice.
author: Paul K.

description: Really yummy, cute, dimly lit ambiance, on a precious corner in SF. Great first date place.
author: p.c. m.

description:
The charming staff is helful and easy to communicate with.
The atmosphere is good for a casual dinner or even a date night.

The price is slightly higher per dish than the place around the corner but I find it to be worth the extra dollar or two.

When I last visited I had the fried portabello mushroom entree.  Amazeballs.

The only thing I would say left to be desired are a few appetizers in 4-6$ range, most of them are 8 or 9.
author: Tom L.

description:
The food is simply mediocre. I tasted the pad thai, the pad kee mao, and one of the currys. None of them really impressed me. There food lacked any spice what so ever.

Where this restaurant really fails is the service. We asked 3 times for more water but never received it.
author: Bill N.

description: I enjoy the food and the company. Very cozy but the parking in the area can be challenging so get out a little early.
author: Billy C.

description:
I do like a good Thai and this place serves up some of the best I've tasted.

The range of foods is really superb and there'll be something for all palates. Special kudos to the coconut rice, which was almost good enough to eat by itself, and the tamarind sauce - which frolics across the tongue like a heard of happy unicorns.

After a couple of meals here I've yet to find anything bad. Portion sizes are good and, while the prices are highish, you get what you pay for. Food quality is good and the cooking superb and that comes at a cost. If you're hungry enough the set menu is very good value however.

The one downside is the music. Thai versions of pop songs might be all well and good in the privacy of a (well soundproofed) home but having to listen to it while you're eating isn't fun unless you're really into that sort of thing. A little less sugar in some of the dishes would be nice too.
author: Iain T.

description:
In 2007 or 2008 this restaurant got strong reviews on a talk show on public TV, and so my partner wanted to try it.  The food was good, the servers were excellent, and the restaurant was comfortable.  We ate there several times.  About a year ago the whole thing began to fall apart.  They raised their prices significantly, the dining room became too crowded because their popularity had grown, and the staff weren't as attentive.

The final blow was when they put an extremely hot pepper (wasabi?) in my partner's dinner and I accidentally ate it.  It hurt so badly that I started crying.  To compound the situation, the server had an attitude about it.  She thought it was something mild like a bell pepper, and that I was overreacting.  

We don't go there anymore.  The hot pepper contributed to it, but the real reason is because they charge too much money for a casual venue.
author: Camille B.

description: Quality Thai food, good service, nice ambiance.  Prices are high so will only be able to go here once in a while.  But it was good.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I love, love, love Thep Phanom. It's a little pricier than the average my-refrigerator-is-empty-so-I-guess-I'm-going-out restaurant, so I really only save it for special occasions or for when friends are visiting from out of town.

I've just never had Thai food that is so well cooked. They also have great vegetarian options. I recommend the crispy fried portobello mushroom served with crispy tofu and braised eggplant in basil sauce. It's both delicious and filling. Also, their pad thai is better than any pad thai I've ever had, and I've had lots.

The service is friendly, and sometimes they wear ridiculous poofy white pants or Hawaiian shirts, which just makes the experience all the more enjoyable. 

It gets busy on weekend nights, so it's a good idea to call ahead to get a reservation.
author: Beth K.

description:
Food presentation is fantastic but basso nova renditions of Michael Jackson's Thriller album playing while you eat a sweet dish of Tamarind Fish (Tilapia to be exact) may kill the dining experience. It will definitely slaughter a dating experience if you and your date aren't enjoying great conversation! 

So, if you can get past the music, the food is excellent! Flavorful and fresh and just the right amount to fill your belly. As others have already stated, the atmosphere is delightful, the food presentation is creative and it is very clean. Again, I can only speak for the food I had, which was the Tamarind fish but it was wonderful, for sure. I'll definitely return to try their specials!!! Definitely a great Thai restaurant!!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
I love Thai Food and have been unimpressed by the Bay Area's selection of good Thai restaurants until I discovered Thep Phanom. 

We arrived with a party of 11 and they didn't even blink an eye, they set up the tables quickly, brought drinks and shortly thereafter they took our order.

The food came and was impeccably displayed. We split some appetizers, had a few dishes and finished out the night with a couple of deserts. 

They were attentive, the food display was creative and well presented and the food was delicious. I would go back in a heartbeat. 

If you are thinking of going here, don't delay, the decor could use a little sprucing up (it is very clean though), and the food is amazing.
author: Heidi S.

description: The poor to mediocre reviews are correct, in my opinion. Despite good service and a nice setting, the food is not that great. The prices are average, but who cares if the food's not good! There are definitely better Thai places in the city. We will not be returning here.  p.s. The muzak is funny for a few minutes, then gets weird and annoying.
author: Lisa E.

description:
First, I consider myself a Thai food snob.  After 5 foodie trips to Thailand and trying at least 12 different Thai restaurants in San Francisco I have a pretty good reference. We went to Thep Phanom to try one of the only Thai restaurants in the city of any notariety that we had not experienced and found it to be really good.

We ordered the Prix Fixe for $20 which was a good deal.  Without the Prix Fixe, I would say that it was a little too expensive which is why I don't give it 5 stars.  For the quality of food, I think it compares similarly with my favorite Sai Jai (just a little more expensive).

The atmosphere was nice which would make it a nicer than average Thai place to take someone who doesn't appreciate the typical hole in the wall.
author: foodiewithadrawl S.

description:
The food here is pretty fantastic but you pay a premium for it. After crunching the numbers and salivating over a number of dishes, I came to the conclusion that the 3-course prix fixe dinner was the way to go. I chose the minced chicken rolls, veggie coconut soup, siamese steak. I also nibbled off my friend's fried tofu and pad thai. I found portion sizes to be average, minus the giant heaping plate of fried tofu. Soup, steak and pad thai were particularly tasty. 

For a 3.5 average restaurant, people seem to know this place has bomb food. It was a packed house late on a Thursday evening, which created a fair amount of noise but what can you do. Props for being superior to the chain gang of King of Thai and Osha (sorry, Bryan B.!).
author: Susan L.

description:
Parking is an absolute nightmare here.  Then again it's the city. I expected it.  
This small joint is located at the corner of Waller and Fillmore.  It was around 8 PM and the place was packed.  The tables are very close together and you're forced to clearly hear the loud table next to you at their increased decibels of whatever malarkey that they're talking about.

There's a small bar and one television hanging on the wall.  We ordered the chicken wrapped appetizer that had a great sauce, a salad that was a bit overkill with the lemongrass, the pad thai which was amazing and some shrimp dish that wasn't hitting the spot for me. The servers were friendly and they all worked together.  Each time someone came to our table it was a different person.  They were kind of eyeing to see if we had paid the check yet. The evening was dying down and there were other open tables now so I don't think the hovering was necessary.  The food was definitely good though.  I took the rest of the pad thai home with me and had it for lunch the next day.  I love pad thai.
author: Bernadette M.

description: In general speaking, the Thai food is good. But the price is little bit high than it should be. Environment is good for couples, friends hang out. I recommend the fried rice( with beef).
author: Sophie S.

description:
I ate here for the first time recently and I was disappointed.  The service was fine, but the food was only so-so.  I ordered from their fixed price menu, which is a good deal at $20 for three courses. The first course, two deep-fried packets of corn and chicken, was okay, but a challenge to eat.  The second course, tom kha gai, the ubiquitous coconut soup I usually love, was sort of pedestrian.  It was so full of inedible flavoring ingredients that I had to fish out large, tough pieces of lemon grass, galangal, etc. with every bite--ironic, considering the lack of complexity in the flavor.  Folks, strain your soup.  A piece or two I don't mind, but this was much too much.  The folks at the adjoining table were having the same experience with their soup.  The pumpkin/shrimp red curry entree had four chunks of pumpkin and two prawns, and the curry was sort of an unimaginative one-note flavor.  Hot, but just not...good.

Here in San Francisco it's easy to become jaded with the number of really good Thai restaurants (three excellent ones within about five blocks of my house, for example) that a mediocre one stands out more than it might elsewhere.  Maybe the un-price-fixed menu features more imaginatively-prepared food.  I really wanted to love this place, but I just couldn't.
author: Earline A.

description: I don't know how this place scored such a good Zagat review, which is why we tried it, but it was below average and overpriced.  A massaman beef, spring rolls, and Tom Yum soup was $34, and all of it was pretty bad.  The beef especially was tough and had been stewing all day.  You've been warned!
author: Gibson V.

description:
This was one of the places that I really missed when I left the city.  I am glad I got to come back and enjoy it.

They have some of the more flavorful and creative Thai dishes that I have had anywhere.

They are currently having a 23 year anniversary special menu, and it was a delicious meal, and definitely great value.
author: Adam O.

description:
Without a doubt the BEST Thai restaurant in the City if not the Bay Area.  My family and I have been going here for over 12 years, and the food and service have been consistently great from day one for us.  

Besides the consistently professional and attentive service and excellent authentic Thai food, Thep Phanom does not use MSG - huge plus!

We enjoy their Happy Hour during which tapas are $5 and drinks are $1 OFF.  

Thep is our go-to restaurant for both ordinary days and special days like birthdays or there's-something-to-celebrate days.  Dependable, consistent, excellent food and service!
author: Chris D.

description: Food was great, but seriously we paid $30 (two $15 main dishes) and they didn't even provide rice! Rice is NOT included. Unreal.
author: Tom P.

description:
I am avery happy to have eaten here.  Last night, all 12 of us were there to experience the great Thai cuisine they offer and of course, multiple bottles of wine! =)

Good service. Very tasty food, I would not mind coming here again .
What did we have?.. hmm..cant remember the names but we had tofu with green beans, fried eggplant dish, another different tofu w/ eggplant, jumbo shrimp on a big slice of grilled pineapple, shrimp curry, spicy chicken dish, fried fish, chicken wings~ stuffed w/ pansit noodles, eggrolls, fried banana desert served w. ice cream, coffee mousse like desert and coffee flavoured creme brulee.  whew.. obviously we ate a lot! =)
ALL dishes were superb! You have to go there and experience it for yourself!

It is a cute little, neighborhood Thai restaurant , on the small side but very authentic. I also thought waiters' outfits were 'cute'..heuheuheu..
I really enjoyed this place and the good crowd that we had. Bliss.=)
author: C A.

description: Heck, I've been eating from this place almost everyday since I can remember *wink*. Still not sick of it. 5 stars!
author: Tip S.

description: One of the best Thai dinners I have ever experienced. The sticky rice was exceptional, the green curry was the perfect mix of spicy, creamy and tangy. Must go back!
author: Serena Q.

description:
I've lived in the Lower Haight for 7 years now and I've never actually walked the 3 or 4 blocks it takes to come and try this place out until this past Friday.  I've heard a lot about it so I was really curious to give it a go.

I still think that these corner restaurants that sit below apartments are always kind of strange.  I mean, would you really want to live above a restaurant and have the savory smell of grease and oil drafting up towards your living quarters all the time?  I wouldn't, but since I don't live above this place I don't really care.

The place was nice and cozy and my friend and I ended up sitting at a table that was literally 6 inches away from the couple next to us.  This is always a weird situation because then you can overhear every word that they are saying and vice-versa.  So we started off with the chicken with spicy coconut soup.  This was some good stuff too.  I'm not a big fan of coconut flavored stuff but this had just the right hint of coconut milk and cilantro.  

Our main courses were the pad-see-ew and prawn, scallops, and calamari with string beans and basil.  Both were pretty tasty but I have to say, for some reason the pad-see-ew was just off tha heez for me.  I don't know what it was exactly, but something about that dish was just really doing it for me.   The only complaint I have about the seafood dish was that I think there was only about one scallop in the entire dish.  The shrimp were nice sized though so I guess that makes up for it.

Overall this is a nice little spot.  Give it a try sometime.
author: D L.

description: I love thai food, and Thep Phanom delivers! The atmosphere is great, the service is excellent and when I was there the speed and quality were superb. The menu has a TON of items, which can make it difficult to try and pick just one. The price isn't exactly the best, but the overall experience makes up for it, and its a small cozy place right off of haight. Check it out if you like Thai!
author: Dylan B.

description:
Wonderful!    I've never had Thai dishes with pumpkin and I tried two different ones here.     I went with two friends and we ordered from the 3 course 19.95 pre fix menu which was such a great deal.    Some of the tasty things we tried and loved were the Crispy Crescent Moon (amazing fried pumpkin) Crying Tiger (incredibly flavorful spicy grilled beef salad) and the Shrimp and pumpkin curry.   

Service was very good and the food came out quicky but with enough time between courses to enjoy.   I would definitely go back!
author: Karen M.

description:
Get the crying tiger beef salad. I have no idea if it is at all authentic, but it's absolutely delicious. The rest of the food I had was pretty good, but when I return, I will get a giant plate of crying tiger beef salad. 

The ambiance was surprisingly pretty. They have large drapes that obscure it from the outside world as well as a cheap, generic open sign (which I have a proclivity to judge since I'm a graphic designer). I've avoided by judging the outside for some time. The inside is actually quite beautiful and modern.
author: Ryen A.

description: We were sat for 20 minutes before we went and asked to have a waiter...bad way to start. Food was okay. Nothing exceptional.
author: Cody H.

description:
The food was good. I recommend the chicken satay, there's just a touch of coconut milk to keep it oh so moist. Ingredients such as calamari, lean pork, eggplant, and green beans are fresh.

But, what's up with the plastic bag liner in each bamboo rice container? My friend and I each had to pull the liner out to dump the remaining third of our rice. The bag is a bit tacky, maybe even unsanitary? Do they think we can use it afterwards to pick up after our dogs?

My friend informed our server the liners were quite odd and the place should bring back the intricate rice bowls they use to have, sans the plastic liner...she said she'd give our feedback to the manager..we'll see.
author: Jonny M.

description:
Very good food and pleasant ambience!  After months and months of Osha, Jitlada and Neecha, it was time to try a different Thai restaurant.  It was very good and I'll be going back for sure. 

Here's what we ordered:
Prix fixe of three items for $20 (great deal!) -- I ordered the minced chicken dumplings, the coconut soup with chicken, and the prawn/pumpkin red curry with basil.  My husband ordered kee mao noodles with tofu, and for an appetizer her ordered the "crispy duo" of corn and taro fritters with cucumber salad. 

Everything was very good.  The soup was a bit too creamy and thick for my taste, but everything else was solid.  The crispy duo was very tasty, as was my curry dish.  The items in the prix fixe were on the smaller side, but it was a nice way to taste more items.

We went on a Thursday night around 8pm.  It was lively, with a few large groups, and several people waiting to be seated.  The place is covered with Zagat ratings and other awards. 

I'll be adding this into my Thai food rotation for sure!
author: Molly P.

description:
Moved to the lower haight pretty recently and am in love with this restaurant. The food is fragrant, flavorful and delicious and you can definitely taste the "wok hai" in their dishes. I love their Chao Phraya salmon, and their Tofu Makur. The South Sea Noodle is a bit on the oilier side but sooo good with the calamari and fish mixed in (I get it without the shrimp cause I'm allergic, and I've never had to send it back because that wasn't communicated by the server, unlike some other restaurants). 

My only complaints are that the food can take a bit to arrive and it's a teensy bit pricier than I'm used to for Thai food (only reason they didn't get 5 stars), but worth it. They also have a three-course prix fixe menu on some nights that lets you choose from a wide selection of the menu, as well as happy hour every day!
author: Lyn W.

description: Truly delicious. I don't know if I've had better Tom Ka Gai soup...although it is always good isn't it? I love it when other people order the whole fried fish. Scares me, but cool to see...from afar.
author: jori m.

description:
I had a great dinner with a friend of mine here tonight. We both ordered off the Prix Fixe. The thep thong (minced chicken rolls) were excellent, with a wonderful presentation, good texture and a tasty dipping sauce. The ambiance, food presentation and service were all good. My friend got the pumpkin appetizer. He wasn't amazed, but I appreciated the texture.

The chicken coconut soup was delicious, and the basil salmon (though slightly overcooked) was also good and altogether the meal portions were just right. My friend's tofu dish was a cut above decent, but he's prone to understatement.

I will definitely be back, and not only because I live just a short walk away.
author: N M.

description:
We were in 5 people and the staff was friendly, but the service sucked.

They brought each person's order with a 15 mins interval, which means that when the last of us got his food, we had all about finished eating.

Food was OK, nothing special. The wait to get the food basically ruined our experience.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Of the 70-some odd Thai places I've been to, only one other restaurant in the city, Suriya Thai on Valencia, has entrees priced at at least $10.  (Expect to pay as much for the appetizers.).  It's just not supposed to be that expensive!  I'm all willing to pay more for good food, but this was too bland to be it.  As much as I was craving dessert, I didn't even bother.  It's easier to accept mediocrity at a cheap restaurant compared to one that's pricier.

I did appreciate the traditional garb on the waitstaff, and the atmosphere is suitable for a date.  But if I want ambiance, I can also head to just about any of the Thai joints in the Marina.  And while I'm there, I can get better food for less money.  Nice try, Thep.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I tried. I swear I tried. I tired to have a mellow night in while all of my alcoholic Yelp friends partook in another DYL, complete with karaoke, hump trains and lots of alcohol. 

I walked in the front door at 7:30 and what did I find? A freakin 420 party in my living room, courtesy of my roomie and his homage to a certain recreational activity he enjoys! Damn, shit, I really wanted to sit on the couch and stare at the TV for hours. 

Well, if you can't beat em, join em....thats my motto, so a few recreational rounds later and smack dab in the middle of the funniest, slowest game of Trivial Pursuit I had ever played in my life, I realized I was hungry....and I mean really hungry!! It must have been all of the laughing that took it out of me, but I was ready to eat the pie pieces off the damn game board!

And then it sunk in....I am a vegan for a month! What was I thinking?? I want a burger, I want a pulled pork sandwich, I want cheese fries and pizza and all of the stuff I can't have!! What am I going to do? What have I done? Why do people celebrate 420 anyhow?? Crap, why can't I have jalapeno poppers and a carne asada burrito? Would anyone know or care if I fell off the wagon (again)??

Well, thank God that Barbara was here, and thank God she brought us all dinner from this Thai restaurant, and thank goodness she is also off the meat and brought things I can eat. It was good. In fact the tofu green curry was the best I have ever had!! Well, it is the only vegan green curry I have ever had, but let me tell ya, it sure tasted good.
author: Drue C.

description:
I bought these beautiful bamboo wind chimes when I was in Thailand three years back. Ok, to be honest, they're just average looking and everyone and their mom, even my mom, has one hanging in their yard. I prefer to hang mine indoors. Why, you ask? Because the sounds of those bitches clinking together is like nails on a freaking chalkboard or the continuous sound of the tape gun in the returns department at my work, which my office just so happens to be conveniently located next to.

Whatever, the point is I find the charming touristy chimes to be obscenely annoying.

Boyfriend and I decided to go out for Thai in my new hood and being the lazy, haven't-walked-more-than-two-blocks-in-a-year couple that we are, we chose Thep Phanom because it was two blocks from my new digs.

Right away I fell in love with the place. No, it wasn't the shiny Sinbad pants the waiters were obviously forced to wear, it wasn't the constant water refills, it wasn't the overall decor, it was the papier mache elephants that greet you when you walk in the door. I LOVE ELEPHANTS! They're my thing. I know it's rather elementary to be obsessed with an animal. For example, I was always totally freaked out by "horse girls" back in sixth grade. Dood! Get a life and stop braiding that Breyer Horse's tail!

But for real, elephants...did you ever know that you're my hero?

Back to the wind chime reference....the ambiance of the place was set by the sounds of what seemed to be a CD of a band who plays chimes as their instruments. It was clinky, weird and not very pretty at all. 

We were pretty ravenous coming into the place and were really let down by our crispy tofu with peanut sauce appetizer. The tofu was completely bland, as tofu is. But it needed more umph! And though the peanut sauce was good, it was a bit watery and needed more peanut flavor.

The Tom Kha Gai was delicious, but the servers seemed really intent on serving our food in courses. And I like my rice doused with a healthy serving of Tom Kha Gai. So we ate a bit of our soup and waited for our final dish and the rice to come. But they kept coming by and asking if we were done with the soup, or if we wanted it wrapped up. Or they would just come over and stare into our obviously unfinished bowls. I finally told them that we wanted our soup with the rest of the food.

The shrimp with chili paste and green beans was good, but nothing spectacular. 

I'll come back because it's ridiculously close to my apartment, but I've got to admit I wasn't overly impressed by the food. I did appreciate them being on top of the water, checking in to see that everything was ok, and promptly bringing us our bill. But the place isn't cheap and the food didn't knock my socks off.

An extra half star for the papier mache elephants!
author: Sammy S.

description:
It's seriously too cold to be typing up a LONG review. My fingers are turning purple/blue while typing so I just have to keep it really short. I might update when I my fingers get back to normal color.

I wanted to try this place for a while now. Ever since I saw it on Check Please Bay Area. Finally got to try it not long ago and it was great, not the best but great. 

Calamari salad was divine, ANGEL WINGS, yummy! It's fried chicken wings stuffed with glass noodles!! Seww gewdd!! (Sorry for my Chinese accent! =P ) That was my favorite dish. The pad Thai, quail on lettuce with the peanut sauce was also great. LOVE the Thai Ice Tea.. I'm like addicted to those suckers!

Service was great and prices were reasonable!
author: Juliane N.

description:
I've been here a few times before but on my last visit I ordered the pumkin curry with prawns.  This is my favorite thai dish and is hard to find in the city, and finding a place that does it well is even harder.  This was the best pumpkin curry I've had.   

The food here is always very good and I count on this place for reliable Thai.  I could do without the cheesy decorations, but it's definitely part of the experience.
author: Laura S.

description:
All of this time, I thought I had somebody down for Whitney.  But it turns out, you were making a fooooool out of MEEEEEE-HEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!!

The wise words of Miss Houston perfectly describe my relationship with Thep Phanom.  They swept me off my feet back in 2001 and dropped me on my fat ass in 2005.  It used to be so delicious and so special that I dealt with the fact that they were cheating on me with thousands of others but enough is enough!  the food is just not good enough anymore to excuse the hour long waits and ridiculous closeness of the seats.

I still give them three stars because change is hard and i am weak. it's hard for me to leave a boyfriend. i still think he'll change back to the man i fell in love with and the abuse will stop. oh this black eye? no, no...i fell. i'm clumsy. it's my fault.
author: Laura B.

description:
So sad.

Thep Phanom used to be one of our favorites when we lived in the lower Haight. Even once we moved to another part of town, we kept coming back because the food was head and shoulders above the ordinary. 

A few years ago, they started sliding. It seemed that the drop in quality coincided with the removal of the specials boards from above the windows. Although it paled in comparison, the food was still very good, and we kept coming back, kept recommending it as our favorite Thai place, kept ugring people to go...

So you can imagine our sadness after eating there twice in the last 6 weeks, and having two mediocre experiences. In December, we ordered a pair of our old favorites -- tom yum goong and crispy basil chicken -- plus salt-and-pepper beef, a new one for us. The soup was bland and unbalanced; the chicken, formerly blessed with a wispy crispy coating, now had a blatant battering; and the beef was interesting but not terribly Thai-flavored, and unpleasantly chewy. We chalked it up to a bad night, and didn't give it much thought.

Last weekend, we went back with a couple of friends. We shared everything, so I had a chance to grasp the breadth of the problem:

Som tam -- green papaya salad -- is typically blazingly hot and pungently tart. Thep Phanom's version was neither. The rather small portion was served in a cocktail glass.

Tom yum goong was dished out tableside into flat soup plates, rather than bowls. The broth was almost clear, not even a hint of redness from steeped shrimp shells or chiles. It tasted almost as bland as it looked: no hot, barely any sour, a paltry 4 shrimp for 4 people. 

Larb ped featured tasty grilled, chopped duck meat, but the rest of the dish was bizarre. There were hardly any greens --typically you eat larb by rolling up the meat and seasonings in leaves of lettuce or other leafy veggies -- and, again, the spice was almost non-existant. Larb is supposed to be HOT!

Basil chicken with crispy basil (gai kprow tod) suffered from the same problems as we noted on our last visit. Very sad... this dish used to be a true standout, a modern riff on a beloved thai classic. Now it wouldn't be out of place at a cheap chinese takeout joint.

Panaeng beef curry was unspicy, badly balanced (sweet flavors completely overwhelmed the salty, spicy tastes) and oversauced.

Thep Phanom is still OK, but it's no longer great. It may not even be better than average.
author: anita c.

description:
This was a decent Thai restaurant in the Lower Haight area. It had a nice clean, quiet ambiance with attentive staff. The food was good but not that flavorful. Actually, it was down right bland as far as Thai food is concerned. This might be a good place to introduce someone to Thai food because their senses won't be over whelmed with interesting flavors. 

I've tried a few Thai places in SF but I haven't found a really great one yet. I will probably try Thep Phanom again just to see if I find something on the menu that is exciting and different and FLAVORFUL.
author: Rex D.

description:
It was my second time here last week, after visiting our friend in the hospital. So I think a review is in order. 

The red curry I ordered was alright. I kinda like my curry with a bit more body, a bit thicker, kinda like Mariah Carrey a couple years back. (Don't you think she's a little on the thin side now??!?) This curry was kinda thin and watery. But tasted decent. The pad thai was pretty good too. My husband and our friend enjoyed the duck curry. 

The soju cocktails are definitely worth a try. I've had the lychee cocktail each time and for 6 bucks! You can't beat that! A slight buzz with your meal is always appreciated. 

Service is fast and friendly. Prices are decent. $65 was our total tab last time: 3 entrees and 2 drinks. They also have brown rice.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I fall into this trap whenever I am in a thai restaurant.

The Pad See Ew trap.  

I've passed Thep Phanom on many a walk home from The Mint, but never thought about going in. Looking for food in the Lower Haight, a friend and I decided this was the place to go as the other 2 thai options on Haight just didn't cut it.  (I only order Chili Cha Cha for delivery)

It was crowded but we were promptly seated in the back and I proceeded to have an extremely pleasan dining experience.

The ambiance inside is nicer then most little thai places.  The bar in the back is cute and the place was alive with chatter and good lighting.

I scanned the menu and could not decide.  This was one of those thai places that didn't have pad see ew on the menu.  Finally free of my pad see ew shackles, I was free to try something new!  Who would have thought that I could partake in a new thai delicacy!  Freedom!  

They were offering a fixed price 3 course menu for their anniversary and it seemed the smartest thing to do to get an appetizer, a soup and an entree for $17.95.

My meal started with an awesome little plate of crispy wantons filled with minced chicken and corn.  There were only 2 of them and i was grateful for that, because the diet doesn't really call for anything fried. They weren't greasy in the slightest.

This was followed by the Thom Kha Gai which was a good balance, all lime and cocunut milk (The diet doesn't call for cocunut milk either so I took it easy and left most of the broth behind).

My entree was the spicy basil salmon, which totally delivered in spicy, not too much, but just enough.  The portion, again, not gigantic, but enough.  I liked their sizes as this ensured you could have a 3 course meal without feeling like a manatee afterwards. 

I love that they offer brown rice.  The brown rice was fluffy and good and not crunchy and sad like when I try and make it.

The staff was great and they let my friend and I loiter at our table for 2 hours after we finished eating.  

I cannot wait to go back!
author: Jen I.

description:
At someone's highest recommendation, we went here on a Saturday night. Letdown. Then I saw that Yelpers had collectively given this place a 4-star rating. Even more letdown, for it's the first time I've really doubted the usefulness of Yelp's future recommendations. At what point does the lack of information about each wildly diverse user, plus the distortions caused by individuals with special interests, begin to flood the system with nonhelpful ratings? I would hate to see Yelp turn into Amazon.com reviews or eBay ratings, where overall numbers cease to mean much and you have to read every single rating of something to (manually) extract any sort of value.  I thought Yelp was special. I thought Yelp was different. Don't be like the others who broke my heart, Yelp.

So, back to Thep Phanom. I can't understand why anyone would put this in their "Best Thai" list. A list of grievances:

0. Not a hole-in-the-wall. How can you expect good Asian food that's presented in such a whiteified interior and proud of its ZAGAT ratings? Nothing says "I am a boring snob who isn't a real foodie but has money to spend and therefore like to think I am cultured, because I rely religiously on this book that all the other boring rich losers read" more than the owning a Zagat guide. Nonetheless, this is not a dealbreaker, merely a warning sign. 

1. Waiters in "The King & I" type, bright purple genie pants. This isn't some exotic Asian show. It's a restaurant. It looks horribly demeaning. But look at the all the reviewers who think the outfits are soooo cool! Geez. Go back to Oklahoma.

2. Red curry was bland. Not spicy enough, and I couldn't really taste any of the spices. The only thing carrying the curry was the coconut milk, but that's like saying, I went to French Laundry and thought the prepackaged mints I ate while waiting to be seated were tasty. 

3. Ginger chicken was bad. Seriously, not even good. Way too salty, especially the black mushroom fungus that accompanied it. Not spicy at all. Not much flavor. 

4. They didn't even bother asking what level of spiciness we wanted on anything. Do you ever go to a steakhouse and they don't ask you how you want your steak done? 

It's depressing just thinking about how not good this place was, how Yelp failed as a trusty resource, and how many tastebud-less, unadventurous (how hard is it to find good thai in SF?!), un-foodies there are ruining these ratings. 

I need a drink. Someone mentioned there was a bar across the street...
author: Gloria L.

description:
My brother Daniel took me out to dinner tonight.  He's my favorite brother.  'Daniel you're a star. . .' (sing Elton John)

We went to Thep Phanom.

I love elephants so thai food restaurants are always a fun time for me.  Thep Phanom has great elephants and a cozy interior.  I like the corner location which must translate well from a feng shui perspective because the place has nice energy.  

We ordered the siamese rolls, the tofu and veggies in lemongrass sauce, and the large prawns with lime in coconut sauce.  The rolls were perfectly crisp with the right amount of vegetables inside, and lovely sauce.   The tofu was breaded, and the veggies were fresh and crisp.  The shrimp was extremely fresh but the coconut sauce with the lime wedges was AMAZING.  I was using a spoon to finish the sauce it was so good.  

The service was sweet.  The people are all so polite and attentive.  I love their cute outfits which make the whole dining-in experience a nice change from all the other hip and trendy new restaurants.

I look forward to trying out more of the menu and will now consider take-away since it's right around the corner.  

Yeah elephants, yeah thai food, yeah thep phanom!
author: James M.

description:
The people who give this place 1 or 2 stars seem very adamant about its suckitude, but I've always enjoyed the food here.  Maybe I don't know what good thai food is or something.  Maybe "inconsistent" is a quality that Thep Phanom possesses.

In any case, I can only review based on my personal experience and expectations.  I REALLY like the food here--the "Weeping Lady" dish with chicken, eggplant and crispy basil is wonderful, and the Pad Thai is in the upper quadrant of good Pad Thai's I've had.

Yes, the ambiance is a little over-the-top fancy, and yes, the prices are not that of an hole-in-the-wall Thai stop.  I didn't even notice any puffy "King and I" pants--maybe they've changed their servers' dress code.  But the service itself was fine.  

Are there cheaper Thai places in the city?  Surely.
Are there better Thai places in the city?  I have yet to find a place I like more, but then I haven't scoured all the outer Richmond and Tenderloin hole-in-the-walls.

Within its neighborhood radius, Thep Phanom is probably the best bet for a quality Thai meal.  If you are a hardcore Thai connoisseur and think that fancy Thai served on white tablecloths can't be good Thai, then don't go here.

If you are in the area and on a date, or up to drop a little extra on a very fine meal, then by all means, give Thep Phanom a try.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Uh... really expensive? 

Thai food is never that expensive... especially for the mini sized portions. 

What? 2 hard earned bucks for a scoop of rice? Are you nuts? I guess it pays for those nice clothes they wear in there. 

Iono... I could get the same food cheaper, maybe not the service... .but that just means less tip. Win- win in my opinion.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
Pretty good, pretty good!  I did not see pad see ew on the menu, so I couldn't order my "usual" for comparison purposes.  I was, however, delighted to find pumpkin and prawn curry as one of the specials.  The curry was very tasty albeit a bit too sweet for my taste.  

The restaurant is more cozy and traditional than modern and trendy, which is a nice change of atmosphere from Osha (although I do love Osha).
author: Grace W.

description:
Update: downgraded from 2 stars to 1, after I eating really good Thai for less elsewhere. I didn't realize how crappy and how much of a ripoff this meal was. 

Terrible place for vegetarians - you have been warned! The veg section on the menu is extremely small and oddly, almost every item is deep fried. We settled on the corn cakes (average and better at Marnee) and the fried mushroom and eggplant. The latter didn't have any sauce and was extremely tasteless. I stopped eating after a couple of bites bc it wasn't worth the calories.

After everything I had heard about this place, it definitely did not live up to the hype. I suspect that TP and Ploy II both used to be great places in their own right, but now they have passed the torch onto places that want to work for their good name, rather than just rest on it.
author: Shal J.

description: Absolutely the best thai food in sf! My husband and i haven't been in many years and it is still so solid!! Delicious thaitanic beef, poached salmon in curry sauce. Excellent service! So worth the trip across town!! Just delicious!!
author: Simone H.

description:
Lonely Planet wrote, "Possibly the best Thai restaurant in San Francisco."  Yelp, of the 40 reviews, averages it to 4-stars, and to top it off, one reviewer stated, "When a restaurant is always busy, there is usually a good reason."  I figured all of the above are enough reasons to check it out.  

I walked in excited and eager, and I walked out feeling disappointed and slightly misled.  Could it be that the reason why it was so busy was due to the other people following the 4-star yelp review?  Or were they also guidebook readers, seeking the ultimate Thai experience that Thep-Phanom is famed for?  

Perhaps, in some distant past, they did have a claim to such title.  However as of today, the crown belongs to someone else, and the search is on.
author: Sha D.

description: I walked by this place on a recent Sunday afternoon on my way from a massage to the mint to meet our housemate John for some Karaoke. I looked at the menu and decided we should have dinner there. And we did. I was really impressed. The service was great and the food was excellent. The flavors were really authentic. Definitely a come back to place.
author: Nobbi L.

description:
A lot of dining is wrapped up in expectation, so diner be warned: This is not your dorm-room Thai food. This is the real deal!

Go in with the knowledge that you'll pay more, but you'll walk away with a belly full of memorable dining experience. Be prepared to step outside your usual Pad Thai routine and you'll be rewarded with true Thai flavor and spice.

Finally, go with several people so you can order more and sample everything family-style. Must-haves for us are always the Taro Root+Sweet Potato appetizer with peanut sauce, and the Crying Tiger Beef Salad to start, followed by the Crispy Portobello Mushrooms and Eggplant with tofu and some kind of heavenly curry. If they're offering the Red Curry with Winter Squash and Prawns, jump on it! Chase the spice with a Singha of course.

Khorb koon kaa!
author: Teresa A.

description:
Although I don't consider the food at Thep Phanom to be the apex of flavor, every dish I have had there has been mighty tasty.  Six of us went family-style this past Friday and even though the joint was packed, we had a fun, intimate meal.  We left with bulging bellies and no leftovers.

Whether dining alone, with another, or in a large group, the prices never come close to breaking the bank.  Best of all, the packed house on weekends creates a festive meal and when the wait for a table is long the hostess takes your phone number to call you when your reservation is ready.

The prix fixe menu is a delicious bargain at $18.95.
author: Erin F.

description:
Once the best Thai restaurant in all the land, resting on their laurels and slow staff have made this landmark into a black mark on my places to go.

First of all the prices are completely out of hand.  
They have increased at a rate that outpaces inflation and is double that of any thai restaurant in the 'hood.  Yes, yes, the food is much better but their Thai Ice Tea has always sucked and they look at you like you have 6 heads for asking for brown rice.  

What's worse is, they have let the "always packed" idea go to their head.  Yes, the food is good, the portions generous and well presented but the service gets worse and worse each time I go that I have decided to go no more.
author: Sean S.

description:
I liked the food here - I really did - but I left feeling a little confused. First, you need to make resos here for a Sunday night. Sign of a good restaurant, but in turn, loses that dive Thai restaurant feel that I was expecting, especially when visiting the lower haight on a casual Sunday evening. 

It has nice decor, great waitstaff (and outfits), but a white tablecloth Thai restaurant in the lower haight?  The prices were reasonable, though a tad higher than my usual go-to spot, and don't get me wrong, the food is good, but not good enough to lure me away from my local Thai. If you're in the neighborhood or live in the lower haight, sure, but otherwise, it's not worth the trek.  Just my opinion.

I'll keep Thep Phanom in my pocket as a safe standby when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Defne A.

description:
I've sometimes wondered if thai restaurants photocopy their menus from other thai restaurants.  This isn't necessary a terrible thing - sometimes all you need is a red/green/yellow/panang curry, stir-fry with choice of chicken, beef or pork, or pad thai/drunken noodle/pad see ew noodle dish.

I have, however, been pleasantly surprised by Thep Phenom's decision to break the mold and come up with some creative plates.  The thaitanic beef (please ignore the silly name), weeping lady, ped sawan (duck breast in a honey sauce over spinach) and basil salmon are all good choices.  And don't worry - the standards are all there as well.

The portions aren't huge so you might end up spending more money than you would at most thai restaurants; but the food is good and beats most cookie-cutter thai joints in the city.
author: Jamie Y.

description: Great Thai restaurant a block off from Haight. Nicer end of casual (tablecloths) and attentive staff. Good heat in the food, though I'm sure they could give you more if you asked. Papaya salad and ground chicken salad for $22, both best I've had in a while!
author: Aki N.

description:
I love Thep Phanom, I wish it was on my block.

I've had a number of dishes there and I cannot figure out which one is my favorite, they're all good!

Here's whats impressive:
- The Food, they have a Pineapple Fried Rice that tastes like heaven and is served beautifully in a carved out Pineapple.
- The Atmosphere. It's a charming Thai Style place with perfect lighting and a comfortable vibe.
- They have awesome health code ratings, I think they scored a perfect score the last time they were reviewed by the Health Department (It's posted in their restroom)
- The Service. The girls are super polite and genuine.

It feels like a treat every time I get to eat something here.
author: Gilbert B.

description: One of my favs for years and they are still bringing it... food is fantastic, cozy neighborhood atmosphere, and great service.
author: Brian K.

description:
You've got to give at least a 3-star rating to a restaurant with hot waitstaff, right? And at least 4 stars to a place with hot waitstaff AND take-out patrons who ask you (a fellow customer) for their order because you apparently look like a waitress. Ego boost...NOT!

Ok, so I wouldn't say that Thep Phanom has a particularly good looking waitstaff, but I do like to stroke my ego once in while (while I am not stuffing my face at yummy thai places like this one). My first experience at this Lower Haight thai spot, though, did leave me with that lasting memory of being approached by a certain customer - likely 'cause of my good looks...errrr, or dark hair and slanted eyes. [Side note/rant/"OMG, I still can't believe it!" outburst: The waitresses were all wearing head to toe traditional thai outfits....and I was in my typical jeans, tank top and ponytail...?!]

Anyway, funny experience aside, dinner here at this neighborhood dining spot, was quite delightful. All the dishes have catchy, yet strange names like "Weeping Lady" - name aside, that dish, although supposedly delicious, did not appeal to me. We did have a yummy tofu, eggplant, squash basil stir fry and a fried spicy prawn dish. I wouldn't get the prawns again - and but the tofu dish is a repeat. Other mouth watering dishes that I spocked and will likely try next time include the special quail dish.

Prices - 3 stars: Ave. - pricey for thai 
Ambiance - 4 stars: Comfortable, clean with a flatscreen playing the Olympics (yeah, I almost choked up the prawn at the beautiful site of Phelp's Speedo clad body)
Service - 5 stars: Attentive, friendly and HOT ;)
Food - 4 stars: Fresh, tasty but slightly too "Americanized" (I know, who am I to say...)

On a date, casual dinner with friends or early night spot before drinks in the 'hood - check out my friends at Thep Phanom - just don't ask ME for your take out order. ;)
author: Deann M.

description:
This place is the thepest Phanom in the city.  

I don't eat here as much as I used to but still a great place to bring out of towners who want a reasonably priced yet delicious thai meal, only a few doors down from my home.  I recommend the braised pork, although they only seem to have this on the specials sometimes.
author: Jeff S.

description:
We were immediately seated at around 8:30 p.m. on a Saturday night, which was nice. I really liked the ambiance here. We ordered the Kaeng Pumpkin with fried tofu and the Chef's Famous Basil Mushroom. Both dishes were balanced, flavorful, and had a dose of "funk" in the best way possible. 
However, neither dish was particularly spicy. We asked for hot sauce and they gave us a really tasty and spicy (housemade?) chili garlic sauce/paste. It really livened up both dishes.
The rice is served in really cute individual woven baskets. In fact, the general ambiance is very nice at Thep Phanom.

I would love to give this place 5 stars but they gave us the wrong sake (they do have an impressive selection) and the service was spotty (it was pretty busy, though). I shall return.
author: Erin M.

description: I think the food here is great and deserves 4.5 stars. However, I ordered delivery from here the other night and was told it would take 45min.  I had to contact the restaurant twice and finally got my order in an hour and a half. The restaurant claimed their driver had gotten in a fender bender, but my food arrived piping hot, which I assume wouldn't have been the case had it been made when it should have been. I had pre-tipped delivery through eat 24 and asked for some sort of discount, and they offered none. Definitely a dine-in recommendation only, as their delivery system is never accurate.
author: Chris G.

description:
Very mediocre on my visit - there is better Thai to be had in the city for comparable or cheaper prices - a few that come to mind are Be My Guest, Thai Stick on Filmore or even Osha Thai.

Green Papaya Salad - I love green papaya salad but I did not care for this version - overly vinegary and salty; no embellishments like crushed peanuts, dried shrimp or dry roasted garlic slices as I'm used to having it served. Appearance resembled sauerkraut, which didn't help.

Stir-fried catfish - special of the day; the fish itself was salty and the dish didn't come with enough sauce, so it felt a little dry.

Red curry with shrimp - this was okay; a generous portion & came with a good amount of vegetables, but the shrimp was a bit tough and the curry was nothing special.

The dessert was actually the saving grace of the meal; they had a fair amount of choices and the bananas foster we got was pretty excellent - large portion of bananas, berries & ice cream atop some kind of cakelike brownie.

Maybe it was an off-night, but  I don't think I'll be going back - like I said, there are too many other options for better Thai.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
Great place for yummy Thai food! I would definitely recommend reservations but they were also extremely accomodating when our party size doubled at the last minute. They also turned on the TV so the lone male of the group could catch his basketball game. 

Cool decorations, fun atmosphere, and most importantly, great food. Be warned  - although you should always expect Thai food to be spicy, even the dishes not described as such were incredibly spicy! Try any of the Chef's specials/favorite dishes - with the exception of one, everyone loved the dish they ordered.
author: Lauren B.

description:
If I can't complain about a single thing, then I have to give it 5 stars, right?  Wait a second, that sounds like I didn't enjoy it. I loved Thep Phanom.  

We showed up on a Saturday night. Five of us. 
The hostess asks, "Do you have reservations?" 
Gulp. 
"No" 
She returns and tells us "twenty minutes?" 
"Of course!!!", we reply.

We saw something on the menu while we were waiting, prawns with fried portabellos, but it was a Sunday, Monday, Tuesday special.  What were we to do? Good thing my friend Rachelle doesn't embarrass easily. She asked if it could be made, and they gladly accommodated us!  (Anthony was glad she asked, but still embarrassed!)

The whole meal was delicious! Fresh Veggie Rolls, Eggplant Basil and Green Beans, Yellow Curry with Fried Tofu and Veggies, Spicy Fried Prawns with Crispy Basil (WOW), Pad Thai, and the special that wasn't on the menu.

One of my friends can't eat spicy food, and although most dishes one the menu are spicy, we managed to find 4 that weren't at all spicy so she could eat them and they were enjoyed by all of us!

Good beer, and my friends enjoyed their thai iced tea.

all I can say is that I'm glad I live so close by, and that they do takeout.  

why had I not been here before?!?!!?
author: Markell M.

description:
I live right around the corner and after about a million visits, I'm finally ready to review Thep.  Get ready, this is gonna be long one...

Definitely lacking on the noodle front -- both the pad thai and the silver noodles are eh; not enough spice, sauce, veggies or tofu (might be better suited for a meat eater though).  They do NOT serve pad see ew which saddens me to no end but c'est la vie! because the fried portobellos make up tenfold for the noodles.  

Big, crispy fried portobellos, gooey eggplant, and perfectly cooked cubes of tofu with basil leaves and just a tiny bit of sauce.  Best combined with sticky brown rice.

Aso love the papaya salad with fresh grape tomatoes thrown in, which is uber refreshing in that sweet and sour kind of way.  

The thaitanic tofu is tangy and a bit spicy -- it's crispy tofu with cucumbers and basil but the menu gives us no clue as to what the spices are saying only "It's the sauce that's Thaitanic!" 

All of the curries are super creamy and not too spicy which is right up my alley.  I know that they can up the spice anty  though if requested.  My only complaint on the curries is that the green is a little lacking on veggies -- might wanna ask for extra.

They have recently added Stag's Leap and Opus One to their wine list, which is a huge step in the right direction (old wine list used to be a who's who of the bottom shelf of Safeway's wine isle).  They've also added soju cocktails and a kinda makeshift bar/bartender in hopes of getting some of the yuppie business from RNM and Nickie's on Haight St. 

Overall: bad noodles, awesome everything else, fun decor, good service, and improving wine list.
author: Abby M.

description:
Yes, Thep Phanom is as good as it gets, truly.  We've been eating here for about ten years now, but since moving to Los Angeles haven't been there in a while.  We decided to take my in-laws there for an early dinner, and I'm so glad we did.

We had moo prig king, pad thai, a sea food dish in a coconut sauce, and crab stuffed prawns.  Everything was simply outstanding.  Pad thai prepared to perfection; moo prig king spicy and succulent.  The sea food dish had prawns, calamari, and scallops--all excellent.  The crab stuffed prawns were glazed and served with roasted pine apple.  Generous portions.

In my ten years of eating here I've never so much as had an overcooked prawn or calamari.  The floor plan is a little crowded, and if you go during prime hours you'll likely wait a bit for a table.  But trust me, this place is very much worth the wait.

Oh, and price?  Good lord, they could increase their prices by 50% across the board and it would STILL be a bargain.  No complaints.  Only praise.  You must eat here.
author: Jaime B.

description:
I went to this place Saturday night with three friends.  We waited a half hour, but went across the street to Cafe Soleil to have a beer in the meantime.  There's not really a good space for waiting there.

We split the spicy papaya salad and vegetarian spring rolls.  I had pork and string beans in peanut sauce, my boyfriend had spicy pork and string beans, friend A had red curry and friend M had some vegetarian thing i don't think I tried.

All of the food was great -- I would def. say one of the better thai places in the city.  The service was also really good and I loved the vibe.
author: Anne O.

description:
Thep Phanom is absolutely my favorite (nice) restaurant. We went last night for my mom's birthday and it was the perfect meal. Naturally, I stuffed myself. My favorites were the beef and potato curry (massaman?) and the special of fried portobello mushrooms and prawns in chili sauce. I love, love, love when the food still tastes good all mixed together at the end of the meal and these dishes did not disappoint. Scooping up yet another serving of rice, I finished up far to many of the dishes. I usually don't care about service, because I like places like Tu Lan where you have to wait outside on 6th street before being served, but the service at Thep Phanom is exceptional. The waitstaff is super sweet and because there's about a 1 to 2 ratio of waiters to customers, food is served PIPING hot and fast. They literally swarm the table refilling waters, taking orders, and delivering plates. 

Basically, I love Thep Phanom.
author: Mairead J.

description:
This was our favorite take out since our first date about 7 1/2 years ago, but tonight was probably the last.   This has always been a treat for us but over the last 3-4 years things have really taken a turn for the worse.  There is only one dish we order EVERY time: the crispy chicken with crispy basil.  Unintentionally, this has become our gauge.  Sad to say the consistency has always been a problem.  The portions varied drastically, and the amount of the delicious sauce fluctuated from swimming in it to merely a mist, like those annoying fragrance models at the mall are dishing it up!   The only thing that has been consistent has been the upwardly mobile prices.

Tonight we ordered the Crispy Chicken, Eggplant with tofu, and rice.  It came to $26, that's borderline overpriced, but when we finally got home and broke out the food, there was hardly enough to have a meal...and the chicken was almost sauceless!  

It is so sad when any business becomes arrogant and out of touch with their client base.  I'll tell them about the problems because they should have the opportunity to remedy them before they get the boot and, let's be honest, I'm selfish, I don't want to have to find another restaurant to replace this one.  

Please, I'm begging, Thep-phanom get your act together and bring back the quality and value that's been missing for the past few years and rightfully earn the Best Thai title.
author: Scott M.

description: The best Thai food I've ever had outside of Thailand. Perfect for a nice dinner out. Delicious and not pricey. The waiters have goofy outfits. My favorite neighborhood restaurant.
author: Alex W.

description:
Everyday I crave their chicken sate. It is incredibly tasty and has a cream-like substance that covers the chicken. So delicious.

The Siamese rolls are also to die for.

The pad thai has a unique flavor that I never tasted in pad thai before = but I love it. There are a few big juicy shrimp in it too.

My only complaint is the amount of ice they put in the beverages.

The restaurant is decorated nicely and has a traditional thai vibe to it. The servers are friendly and attentive.

I highly recommend Thep Phanom for anyone looking for a nice dinner out.
author: Katie S.

description: Great spot for authentic Thai food.at reasonable prices
author: jeff s.

description:
We visited the restaurant, and I just read the reviews.  Most are very accurate.  The interior is nice and cozy, the service was very good, but the food was not so great.  They do a very nice job with presentation but quality is very lacking.  We chose from the prix fix menu and were dissappointed.  Would have rather had some good yellow curry and satay.  

What we had was nothing we have experienced at other very good Thai restaurants.  As we approached the restaurant the cooks, I guess, were sitting outside on the sidewalk smoking cigerattes . .not nice.  The Steak dishes were a disappointmnent.  Sliced pe\ieces of steak, thrown over some tough veggies, covered with a somewhat burnt peanut sauce.  Salmon dish was mushy, frozen salmon for sure.  Chef Ramsey would have a ball with this place.

Real nice people and a pretty place.
author: Dave J.

description:
The food here is really really good. The plates are nicely made up, not just thrown together. There is some presentation. But it costs too much. $11.95 for curried chicken? Too much. 

Do you know how many chickens you can buy for $12????

Its a really small restaurant and feels very crowded even when its not crowded. Its very prettily decorated. The wait staff is very nice.

I'd like to eat here more than I do, but I just can't justify spending that much money on food I can cook myself. Or find made closely as well someplace else.
author: Marz W.

description:
The quality of the food is high; the presentation is wonderful; the space comfortable; but the flavor disappoints.  The ingredients used were excellent, but I found all entrees I've tried to be on the bland side with little punch.  I felt as if the cooks were holding back.  I sense this could be a phenomenal restaurant with real curries -- thick and bold rather than frail and hurried.  But it seems they've dumbed it down.  Everything is top-notch except the taste -- which is a real disappointment because most of the Thai restaurants in the area are bigger on flavor but short on quality ingredients (and so many of them use MSG.  I suspect Thep Phanom does not -- though I don't know that for a fact).  It's a shame when less masterful restaurants are able to produce more excitement.  The quality is certainly here; the flavor is not.

I am frustrated with this review because a 3-star review of Thep Phanom doesn't fairly represent the quality and potential of this restaurant.  It would be like giving the movie Shrek four-stars and giving the movie Gandhi four-stars.  Can you really compare Shrek to Gandhi?  Can one honestly say that because their rating is the same that they are equally as good?  The countless other 3-star Thai restaurants in the Bay Area don't hold a candle to the mastery that was expressed in quality, attention to detail, and presentation.   But, once again, there was little dimension in the flavor.  Hence the depressed rating.  I sense that the brilliance is dormant -- much like a smart student who never studies.  She still gets good marks, but not the kinds of marks that she could get.  Whereas other Thai restaurants work for their 3-star ratings, Thep Phanom earns its rating in its sleep.

I emphasize my qualification of this review simply because I've eaten at so many mediocre Thai restaurants in the area.  To equalize Thep Phanom to the majority of Thai establishments seems unfair.  At the same time, it really needs to step up its game.  Despite its lack, I would return.  The disappointment from Thep Phanom is that it doesn't live up to its potential.  The disappointment from the other Thai restaurants is that they are just not good.  Flavor aside, the quality produced from this apparently unconscious kitchen is higher than any other I've experienced in the Bay Area in the past year.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: Not a very good thai place.  The food wasn't that great, and it wasn't that cheap either.
author: Elena L.

description:
I've heard great and wondrous things about this place, but haven't managed to taste them.  I've been twice and both times I've been underwhelmed.

The bad (i.e., entrees): Panang beef was not at all spicy, and although the beef was perfectly tender, the sauce's sugary sweetness overpowered the other flavors.  Crispy basil chicken with eggplant had about six times as much soggy eggplant as anything else.  Birds of paradise (fried quails) were flavorful and crispy, but extremely dry.  Nothing was absolutely terrible, but nothing was good, either.  I get the feeling that some things they have might be great, but I've been unlucky enough never to order them after two trips.

The good (i.e., everything but the entrees): Spring rolls and fried shrimp rolls were great appetizers, and their peanut sauce is absolutely delicious.  Last time I went, my girlfriend and I were sitting next to the chef's pastry school certificate hanging on the wall, so we decided to order dessert.  We got fried bananas a la mode, and it was very good.  It was a banana deep fried, and served in a caramel sauce like bananas foster.  They gave us tons of fruit with it as well.  Service was perfect, and our waters were constantly refilled.
author: David B.

description:
Super cute little restaurant - we went on a pretty packed night - was a good thing we decided to make reservations.

Everything we ordered was delicious from the shrimp rolls and veggie rolls for appetizers - to the pad thai, curry with shrimp and ginger chicken for dinner. I am quite picky when it comes to pad thai and this is one of the best - if not the best - I have had in the city. 

Now for dessert - kahlua creme brulee with sliced strawberries and blueberries on the side topped with a sprinkle of powdered sugar - I think I am in love.
author: Melanie T.

description:
Service is great.  Parking can be a pain.  Food range from ok to wonderful.  

My favorite
crying tiger
their silver noodle (it has chicken and veggie in it)
author: L C.

description:
Thep Phanom came very highly recommended...that's probably why I'm a bit disappointed. Had I just stumbled in, I might be singing a different tune. I've been twice now, and while both experiences were pleasant, I was told to expect the food to be outstanding.

The Tom Yum soup didn't have the flare I was hoping for, and I remember thinking last year that the satay we tried was the same as everywhere else. Each of the entrees I've tasted [family style is definitely a good way to hedge your bets and share the reading responsibility when choosing from a menu with 76 items] has been pretty good...none as good as the crispy tofu [I'm not usually high on vegetarian dishes, but this was worth it]. The King and I [a specialty dish] left me thinking that I should have ordered a Thai staple instead of making things interesting. My friends really liked the curries. Maybe this is the sort of Thai restaurant that does the simple dishes best. I'll keep that in mind next time...when craving Thai, go with the staples.

The atmosphere and service happen to be perfect, though...cozy, comfortable, cheerful. I recommend giving Thep Phanom a try with reasonable expectations, especially if you live in the Haight or Hayes Valley and it could become your neighborhood spot for Thai.
author: Jon W.

description: I've always loved this place, especially when it was steps from my last apartment. However, I was really disappointed to discover that my favorite dish Pad See Ew was completely flavorless and almost sticky and mushy in texture. I was happy to see the addition of this dish to their daily specials menu because they had never carried it before, but they should've left it off. I was considering taking 2 stars off for this, but I love all of their items too much. Everything else is consistently tasty and the presentation is nice for a small local thai place.
author: Sonya D.

description:
Thep Phanom.  This place was ph'a'nominal.  Okay, had to get that out of my system.

Anyway, this place is so fucking good it's forced me to re-evaluate the other Thai restaurants I've reviewed on this site and bring them down a notch.  Really.  It's that good.  I mean, even their Thai iced tea is more spectacular than the Thai iced tea available at other restaurants.  And this is just Thai iced tea, folks.  It's not that complicated.  Tea, milk, sugar.  But it's better!  Here!  Here, it's better!

Their only problem - and it's not enough for me to bring it down a star - is the wait.  I've found that most Thai restaurants in the city tend to be able to seat you pretty close to imediately.  Not so with this place.

But there's a reason for that.  See how that works?

Also, their menu is huge, and occassionally has crazy names on it like "Three's Company" and the "Pad Thai."  Crazy, huh?  Pad Thai... where do they come up with it?
author: Igor N.

description:
Ok, so like many other reviewers, I was told that this was THE place for excellent Thai food in the city. The food was pretty excellent, but that is mostly where the good stuff ends for me. 

Besides having to sit so close to the couple next to me that I had to endure some idiot telling his date all about his infected toenail problem during my entree, the staff kept coming by every 30 seconds (i kid you not - I timed it) to fill my water glass. If I didn't drink any, they still filled it, until there was that bizarre water tension effect where the water was actually higher than the rim of my glass, but not spilling out yet. 

The crazy sequined wraps of the waitstaff was quiant, but kind of weird too - all in all, a mediocre customer service experience. Add to that the fact that the restaurant was like 200 degrees from all the food and people and, well, you know.....
author: Nick R.

description: The BEST Thai Restaurant in the city for creativity, service and the taste. This restaurant is owned by my friend but that's not the reason I'm giving it 5 Stars. I Love their unique way of presenting their food and the taste is just amazing. Parking is a little difficult so come before 630pm or take transportation. I would recommend making reservations to guarantee a seat because it does get crowded.
author: Deb C.

description:
My 2005 visit was sad compared to my 1997 visit, the food just didn't compare.  I was blown away my first visit.

There was a special appetizer when my friend Tanya and I went.  It sounded like a tasty seafood dish.  When it arrived, it was a whole fish body fried into the shape of a bowl, with bits of its flesh mixed with melon inside.

We're from Texas.  That fish arrived and was just staring us both in the face with it's little fried-out eyeballs, and we couldn't stop laughing for 10 minutes.

You never recover from that.
author: Jay R.

description: I never had a meal at Thep Phanom that I didn't enjoy.  Not a veg restaurant, but they do have several veg options.  The Thaitanic Tofu is amazing.  Spicy and delicious.  The eggplant is perfectly cooked.  Most places tend to either over or under cook it, but it's perfectly tender at Thep Phanom.  The basil mushrooms are excellent.  The mushrooms melt in your mouth and the fried basil adds flavor and texture.  This is my favorite dish.   The fresh rolls are always incredibly fresh.  They have a really good peanut sauce.  The fried tofu appetizer with peanut sauce is also really tasty.
author: Dana P.

description:
This is the best Thai restaurant, in my opinion, that I have tried in SF! I am a Pad Thai snob and haven't had any great Pad Thai since we moved to the West Coast. I think the Thai food depends on which region they are from in Thailand, but whichever region Thep Phanom is from - I love it. The food reminded me of the Thai food back home.  Thep Phanom was absolutely delicious! I was having a huge pregnancy craving for Pad Thai and Thep Phanom totally exceeded my expectations! We were just driving by and ended up stumbling on the best Thai food I've had in a long time! I got take out, but would definitely eat there in the future. The decor is beautiful and the staff was very nice. Check it out!

9/15/08
I've eaten here several times since and the food is even better at the restaurant. I actually can't do take-out anymore, it just isn't as good. The pumpkin curry and tom kha gai are also very good too. My husband has experimented more with the menu and hasn't been disappointed. Yummy.
author: Keely G.

description: I'm new to the bay area and heard of this place from a friend and LOVED it.  Great neighborhood and the food was fantastic!  Loved the ginger chicken, basil chicken and lemongrass chicken.  We shared all the plates as a group so we got to eat family style.  The ambiance is nice without being too fancy or too casual.  We were also able to get a very affordable bottle of wine with our dinner too.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Karen H.

description:
When a restaurant is always busy, there is usually a good reason. In this case, it's because Thep serves intricate, delicious, eminently reliable Thai food. Because this is a thai _restaurant_, not just thai food, many things are unfamiliar, and you may have to try a few dishes before you find something you're insane about. 

My favorites: The Weeping Lady, Three's Company, Crispy Tofu (only have it at the restaurant, though), Tom Kha Gai (soup)
author: Kevin G.

description:
It's great to find a restaurant that tries to stand apart through its food and not its prices.  We were really impressed with the original variations on the usual thai fare.  There's no reason that a chef shouldn't experiment with standard dishes.  Many people have an ethnic food hang-up, and expect their foods to act in just one way.

We ordered the fried yams and taro in peanut sauce, the Thaitanic Tofu, and the Panang Tofu.  We were really, really impressed by the more intricate flavors that each dish had.  We will always notice when thai food isn't spicy, and were shocked when looking back, after reading a few yelp reviews, to realize that it wasn't at all.  And we scare people with how spicy we like our food.

The yams and taro were fried perfectly, with an amazing sauce and were served standing up in two aperitif glasses, rimmed with peanuts, making them envied by the next table.  Damn good.

The panang was a particularly smooth and rich curry...  with fresh pineapple instead of the usual canned, and was not too salty.  There was tons of crispy fried basil and cherry tomatoes, which was a fantastic addition.

The Thaitanic tofu was delicious with a very pronounced kaffir lime flavour.  There was something very subtly heart-wrenching about it.  Or at least it made one of us consider licking the plate...

On a previous visit:  The crispy basil chicken was the best I've had in the city.  Tons of crispy basil and amazing fried chicken instead of the usual stir-fry.  The prawns in the red curry were HUGE, and well not that huge, but they were large and damn fine quality.  You get the idea.  As all the ingredients here seem to be.  Oh yeah, and the curry had a refreshingly strong lemon grass aroma.

And any place that would give out a free glass of wine for their anniversary is just cool.  The waiters and waitresses were really nice, and move really quickly, even when they were dealing with the one downside of our meal, the huge and rude birthday party of people who were so bad that no other patrons even chimed in to sing to the birthday boy.

Anyway, we still cant wait to go back and save some room for the desserts because they looked awesome at the other tables.  We found that it was a really good deal for such excellent food, with such original tastes, oh, and very pleasant decor.
author: Nicole and Kayvon B.
