description:
Got dinner here the other night. 
If we didn't order the Stuffed Chicken Wing, it would have been worthless. 
The red curry with pork - eh, not too bad. salty
The pad thai- came with a lemon wedge, taste was non-existent 

But the chicken wing is amazingggg
Try the stuffed chicken wing
author: john q.

description: Awesome Pretty Balls, Shrimp Rolls, and Crying Tiger... :-)
author: Michael A.

description:
Love the presentation of the food, it made getting every dish exciting.  All of the food tasted great too.  Had a $5 app for happy hour and it was one of the best fried spring rolls I have ever had.  Definitely reminiscent of the egg rolls from back east.  
Had a few veggie dishes and am excited to go back to try some meat dishes next time.  The staff was also very friendly and helpful.
author: nicole k.

description:
The 2 of us ordered the Prix Fixe for $20 which was a good deal.  We had the thai beef salad, tom yung soup, chicken wings, chicken rolls for our starters.  All were well done and yummy, esp. the thai beef salad and chicken rolls.  The soup was ok, not sure what it was missing, it was lemony but maybe needed more of a kick.  For entrees, we had the BBQ ribs and shrimp/pumpkin curry.   Tjhe servings were a bit small, but what can you expect.  The curry shrimp was deelish, although you only get 2 jumbo shrimp.  The ribs were overcooked and a bit dry, but came with a nice sweet and sour sauce.  We also ordered the pad thai, and it was flavorful and nicely done.

The atmosphere was nice, the service was excellent.  Would go back!
author: Paul C.

description: I thought this place was excellent. The panang beef was chock full of crispy basil leaves, and the beef was tender, and the sauce great. It knocked my socks off.  All the food my neighbors ordered looked excellent as well -- and more unique. It was a tad expensive and they took a long time to take our order. My rating is subject to change to 5 based on a few tweaky contingencies.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Cute little place with some good Thai food.  

We made reservations ahead of time for once and skipped waiting in the tiny little corner room, looking on as everyone else dined.  

The chicken satay was a little overcooked but the chicken was still flavorful.  As I recall, there's a lot of crying and weeping involved in the menu: Weeping ladies, crying tigers. We ordered one of the spicy salads, which was good but it not spicy at all. And they didn't make our curries hot enough to taste spicy, let alone make us/ladies/tigers weep, even though we asked for it. Begged really.  Oh well, the food was still good, the perfectly cooked rice was served in cute little baskets, my mimosa delicious, and the service attentive.  Not sure if I will come back though as the place at dinnertime was noisier than a dim sum joint at noon on a Sunday.
author: Violalalalalalalalalalalalalala T.

description:
Eating here you know where youre money's gone - white table cloths, nice curtains and very attentive wait staff - Because the food, its just Thai food.  Its just plain ol' Thai food with ambiguous pieces of meat... Now don't get me wrong Im a huge fan of thai food... It sustained me as a student up in Seattle (some of the best thai I've ever had) and in Thailand itself.  I know what goes into a Green Curry or a Phad whatever.  I know this very well, so when it is priced at 12 or 14 dollars (twice what it would cost at a place like Thai Tom!) And its mediocre, I know that my money has gone to other places, like tricking the customers that this food is something else - something you eat at a fancy shmancy restaurant.

It reminded me of the Indian place up the street.. really typical asian food dressed up as something else.

So Im still in search of some really honest thai cuisine in San Francisco, suggestions?
author: Zachary K.

description:
We've only been to our neighborhood Thai place once, but we were happy campers when we did. The atmosphere is nice -- not too casual, not too fancy -- and the service was friendly.

They have lots of vegetarian options, but I just saw Nicci S.'s review below and now I'm worried that my tofu dish had fish sauce in it. The food was really tasty though, fish sauce or not. We'll definitely go back.
author: Tamara M.

description:
I have been to this place three times and have been consistently disappointed. Maybe it's the quality-to-price ratio but nothing tastes as good as it sounds on the menu. A lot of the dishes taste like some key ingredient is missing. It lacks the comfort food element that makes Thai food such a big take-out staple. They also managed to mess up lemongrass tofu on our last order. It makes me terse and angry.

Their Kahlua creme brulee and tom kha gai are to-die-for good though.
author: Nupur L.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant!  The prix fixe is an exceptional value and a great way to sample some awesome dishes.  Some of my favorites-the dancing lady, Thai-tanic anything, the Tom ka gai soup, crispy mushrooms, spicy prawn salad, the crying tiger salad, I could go on forever.   Fresh ingredients and creative cooking style make this a place that I will be in love with forever
author: the c.

description: Surely some of the best Thai food to be found in SF and in a great atmosphere. It's a little on the pricey side, but it doesn't get much better.
author: James B.

description:
Hm.... I'm a bit worried.  I just moved to San Francisco and am concerned if this is the best Thai that SF has to offer.  

Don't get me wrong.  The food here was good and tasty, the presentation excellent, and the space adequate.  But, compared to Thai restaurants in Los Angeles and Washington DC (the other cities where I've spent enough time to be able to compare), Thep Phanom's food was only average.  

For one thing, it was rather on the bland side.  I'll have to go back and try something from the "spicy" section of the menu to see if that fares better.  But we had a red curry with shrimp which would have been at least a little but spicy at almost any other Thai restaurant and here it was rather weak and milky.

Also, the service was rather poor by SF standards.  We had to ask for the check three times, and they got one dish wrong on our order (we ate it anyway).  

I'd really like to like this place, so I'll be back ... and hopefully will be able to add a star next time....
author: Steve O.

description:
"Time/Date: Friday 7:30 pm

Type/Quality: High Quality Thai Food; can't touch this.

Price/Quanity: Around $55 gets you a dinner for two with some leftovers. Our meal included: a thai iced tea, an appetizer of fried tofu, you should get this, a pot of rice, an entree of curried duck, a special of bass in banana leaf, and all the water you can drink.

Service/Accesibility: The food takes a while and so does seating w/out reservations(*A trick to get seated faster is to request a meal at the waiting bar if its open.). However, the service is friendly and they watch your water like hawks. Parking looks okay but be prepared to park a few blocks away; Hayes Valley is a good place to stroll. 

Structure/Ambience: The venue has a warm bustle, authentic thai decor, close seating, filled tables, and high ceilings .The plates can crowd the table so if you eat family style be comfortable with your company. The service is fully dressed in what appears to be traditional Thai clothing, i.e. neon Hammer pants.
author: Justin L.

description:
I'd just returned from Thailand and I was craving Thai food.  I'd always remembered Thep Phanom to be one of the best Thai places in SF, so I was eager to test out my new found expertise and satisfy my need to capsaicin.

The green papaya salad, the spicy seafood salad, and the larb all disappointed.  They were not spicy at all!  I asked for chilis and instead of the fresh ones I grew accustomed to in Thailand I got dried powder and some strange sauce, neither of which did the trick.

The crispy duck was good though duck is not my thing.  The vegetable curry disappointed.

Boo :(.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Whence the 3 stars, people?  This is the only Thai place I've found in the city at which, with a Singha and a plate of their amazing green curry, I feel like I'm back in Thailand.  I was easy to impress with Thai food before I visited the place where it's from; now, I'm not so easily won.   And this place has my vote.

I'm drooling just thinking about their green curry.
author: Nori H.

description: Thep Phanom is a contender for my favorite Thai in SF--it's certainly the most consistent, and has an extensive and very creative menu that goes way beyond the basics.  Service is always impeccable, and the kitchen will make things genuinely spicy (as opposed to some of the overly sweet flavors some reviews complained of) if you ask.  It's on the expensive side, and it definitely has a lot of competition, but personally, I don't think it's gone downhill.
author: Ty D.

description:
Phuk this place.

Seriously.  It wasn't bad but it wasn't anything I consider above par.  I went to a Thai place in Maine that was better.

It costs a lot, and you're not necessarily going to get your money's worth.

The food + ambiance would give it a 3, but the service was pretty damn shitty-- you gotta earn your 20%.
author: L J.

description:
Always great food. Prices ain't outta control, and portions are perfect, in my opinion.

Great service with a smile, and the decor is rich with stuff to look at. It's a little cramped, but doesn't seem to bother me. 

I suggest the duck curry.
author: Marty K.

description:
To those of you who have not tried Thep Phanom, go enjoy. The food is downright royal. If you want a noodle shop, go elsewhere. If you want Thai Cuisine, come here. 

Many reviewers seem to bemoan that the food is different now than the way they remember it years ago. Being a recent transplant with no basis for comparison, Thep Phanom is easily one of  the best Thai restuarants I've ever been to. The absolute best is the Blue Elephant in Paris. Thep Phanom is close, half the price, and isn't halfway around the world.

I've eaten here twice. Once for a very early weekday dinner when the restaurant was empty, and once with a large group on a busy weekend night. The food was much better when the place was empty, so I'd strongly recommend going during off-hours. 

It seems the kitchen is easily overwhelmed by too many orders, but this is forgivable. Food of this caliber at this price is hard to come by.
author: G Z.

description:
Definitely the best  of the three Thai places in the Lower Haight. BUT...

Poor dining experience. Long wait in a very cramped space, then slow service at very small tables that are really, really close together. Prices aren't expensive, but not cheap other compared to Chili Cha Cha or Visit Thai around the corner.

Also, this place is totally overrated. It's good, but nothing to email home about. Not sure what all the hype is about. Two blocks from my house for the last three years and I've eaten here maybe three times.

On the plus side, though, the waiters wear crazy pantaloons!
author: Josh K.

description:
In SF this week for work and was at a buddy's house with his 3 year old twins.  Needed some food that we could get delivered (or at least to go).  Thep Phanom is closeby and I wasn't thrilled about Thai since I've had so much crappy Thai recently.

What a pleasant surprise.  We had a chicken, beef, and prawn dish.  All were stupendous.  Not greasy, not heavy (even the peanut sauce), but super flavor and textures.  The prawns were obviously fresh (not frozen), and the beef was beefy and not crappy strips from the nether regions of a cow.

Aside - I'm writing this on the plane and the dude behind me literally hasn't shut up for 60 minutes about his Blackberry.  NEWS FLASH: I had a blackberry in 99 - it ISNT COOL ANYMORE.  I'm delighted you can 'message' people anytime as the rest of us have been doing for nearly a decade - shut the hell up so I can type in peace or get a new gadget that someone might care about.

Back to Thai - good food for takeout - would recommend it if you're near Castro in SF....
author: Stefan W.

description:
Food was pretty good but didn't seem to match the slightly steep prices.  We tried the Grilled Octopus (which was really grilled squid), MassaMun beef, the Pad "J" (eggplant and string beans), and Pad Thai.

Maybe we were paying for the atmosphere.  The restaurant itself has a very romantic air.  It is dim but not dark, it has close but not too tight tables, and all around us couples were speaking in hushed tones.  P and I played along and had a really nice time.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
It's the Thep Phenomenon.

These bastads have mastered the art of tofu-cooking. Lady fingers, or pretty lady, whichever dish has prawns on a stick - delicious. Their thom kha is also very good. 

You might have to wait forever for a table because it's always packed. The traffic volume might be an indicator that you won't regret the wait.
author: C P.

description:
This is my boyfriend's FAVORITE Thai place and he finally took me there Wednesday night.  Honestly, I was not impressed, or at least it didn't meet my high expectations.  The place itself was cute and very neighborhood-y so that was nice. Service was okay - nothing to write home about.  

The cucumber salad was pretty dry, not the best. 

The Chicken Satay appetizer however, was really fantastic and is the only reason why I liked this place at all.  The peanut sauce was different than the usual and really tangy, and the chicken skewers were incredibly moist. Well done dish for sure. 

The Pad Thai was also very dry and subpar in my opinion, since this is the dish that every Thai restaurant should be getting right. Not a lot of sauce, no real peanut flavor, only 3 pieces of shrimp in the whole dish and it was very dry.  

My guy ordered the Tilapia with Green Curry & Coconut milk (which appears to be the same dish the girl below ordered). The curry and coconut milk combo was delicious but the fish was awful. It was a project for him to eat as it arrived on this big wooden boat thing, full fish head with scales, brown and crispy, the fish was curled up and it was impossible to get to the meat beneath the scales. He spent the entire dinner trying to get to the fish and it was just not pretty.  

Mai Thai was okay, and be sure to try the Phuket beer.  

Also, not very cheap for a neighborhoody place. $75 with tax and tip for  1 dish, 1 1/2 appetizers, 1 noodle dish, some rice and 3 drinks.
author: Christine S.

description:
I ate here Sunday night on a recent trip to SF.  I like Thai food, just not so much the food served at so called Thai Restaurants.  Honestly, I've had better Thai food at the airport in Bangkok than most places in the US.  Almost always, the menu's have the usual suspects and no one place makes it less greasier or less generic than another.  But the food at Thep Phanom was pretty good, if only for the fact that their menu was more interesting and varied.  

We started with the Crispy Tofu (love the peanut sauce...I couldn't stop eating it).  I had the Thaitanic Beef & though not extremly spicy & I LOVE spicy, it was a nice change of pace.  My dining companion had the Panang Nuer which he said was okay.  But then again, Mr. Fancy Pants actually took a cooking course in Thailand.  

The prices can seem a bit high if you're used to spending $4.99 for the Pad Thai lunch special w/the authentic "Thai egg roll", but it's hardly outrageous.  

The decor...well, it's a neighborhood restaurant...it's colorful & cute...and awfully cozy (aka tiny).  But hardly anything to get worked up over.  I knew I was eating at a slightly nicer neighborhood Thai restaurant & it delivered on my expectations.
author: Soo H.

description:
A must do!  I went to this restaurant for the first time with 5 friends, and we had the best time.  The food was delicious and we received so much of it for only $25 each.  We were all full after wards.  

Some of the stands outs for me were the Crying Tiger salad, pad thai, panang beef curry, and fried tofu with string beans.  The only disappointment was the crispy duck - it was a little too crispy for me.  I really love Thai food, and this restaurant  delivered.  Some of the tastes weren't that authentic, but they were executed well enough.

The restaurant is small, and it seems cramped when you first walk in, but we didn't even notice the surrounding tables once we started.  The service was good, but our server could have been a bit friendlier.  With great food and great company, it didn't really matter!  (The padlocked closet in the men's bathroom kinda creeped me out.  Haha!)
author: Vicente G.

description:
Thep Phanom is hands-down the best Thai food in the Bay Area, but I have to leave off a star, because of their service.

Generally speaking, their service is friendly, but the thing that drives me *crazy* is that they don't honor reservations -- there's no point in even making them!! No matter the time you make reservations for, they'll fill their tables to capacity and you'll inevitably have to wait a good 20-30 minutes or more to get seated, especially if you're with more than 2 people. Their space is small, so you're left with having to wait at their extremely cramped bar where you'll be standing directly in the way of bathroom traffic (this is in no way exaggerated).

With that said, the food's great and well-priced. For appetizer, get their fried calamari -- it's unlike anything else I've had at a Thai restaurant. I've never been unhappy with any of their dishes, so experiment!
author: Joyce S.

description:
I sampled a variety of food from here that we ordered to go.  I loved it! 

The steak salad, green curry, egg rolls and everything were amazing. 

No clue how much it cost since I wasn't paying, but the food was great.
author: Matt V.

description:
Great. (better review soon)

hj,

thais don't use chopsticks in most part of the country.
it makes that place more authentic.
author: Jon F.

description:
I agree with the others than it is not cheap, for Thai.  On the other hand, I got the Lemon Grass Tofu and it was delicious.  To top it off with yummy 6.00 martinis, I can see this as a great reoccurring place for a nice dinner with friends.

I did not have any of the negative dishes mention, and neither did my friends, but everyone seemed to enjoy there meal and the service was good.

I say check it out and make your own conclusions.
author: Becky T.

description:
Why is it that only the mediocore Thai restaurants do delivery? Thep is one of the nicer Thai places in the city... Err, at least in my part of the city.

And sadly they do not deliver. But hey carry out works fine! They always have my meal ready in 15-20 minutes. Solid Thai food, and not too too pricey.

Someone should really open a killer Thai places that actually delivers...
author: Trey F.

description:
When I first walked in I was delightfully surprised by the atmosphere and overall mood of the restaurant. The staff was very helpful and bustling about even though it was only the beginning of dinner service.

The menu was a prix fixe Chef Special commemorating the 25h anniversary of the place, and it was perfectly priced. I ordered the shredded chicken rolls as an appetizer, the Chicken Coconut Soup (which was infused wonderfully with lemon grass), and was apprehensive about the Siamese Beef in the Curry Sauce, but was pleasantly surprised when I tasted the first lick of my fork dipped in the thick coconut curry. The beef was thinly sliced accordingly and the bed of vegetables beneath the sauce and beef was cooked "French" which was nice.

The Thai Iced tea was fragrant and traditional, like it ought to be. No boxed Thai Tea flavor like I've commonly tasted.
author: Trevor A.

description: Food was good but not amazing (props to the nice vegetarian selection though). The music playing in the background was fantastic - cheesy covers of old pop songs like Shout (Tears for Fears) and Material Girl. The mood was mellow. The staff was alright. We were rushed out of the restaurant at 11pm on Saturday when plenty of others were still there, which made for a less than pleasant ending of the night. I have no problem with being rushed out if a restaurant is closing/staff needs to get on with their night, but the restaurant was still full, and instead of explaining to us that they were closing (which they probably weren't), the waiter came back to our table a minute (or less) after giving us the bill and feigned surprise that we hadn't paid yet - he even picked up the bill (a lone piece of paper on the table - no envelope) as if he thought there must have been money/credit cards hiding under it, when obviously there wasn't.
author: Mia M.

description:
I live 2 blocks away from this place, why did it take me almost a year to try this place.  very tasty.  
they had a pumpkin prawn curry special tonight that was AMAZING!! i wish i had ordered this in triplicate as i now crave it.  may have to go back and get more.  also the thaitanic tofu was terrific.
author: Andrew r.

description:
Yum!  This place is excellent.

Possibly my favorite Thai food in San Francisco?
author: Joshua E.

description:
I went there last weekend with a few friends and my girlfriend. It was Saturday, so the wait was expected. Unfortunately, there is no good waiting area and we ended up grabbing drinks across the street. After this tiny disappointment, everything else was just groovy. 

The wait time we got quoted was right on the spot. The service was great, the staff was attentive and efficient. The food was delicious and very reasonably priced. The portions were generous and nicely presented. Timing was great as well. 

The atmosphere was great as well. The staff is wearing interesting outfits (I say interesting, because my friends who happen to both be in Thailand said they haven't seen outfits like that over there). The decor was nice for an eye, comfortable and warm. 

It is truly one of San Francisco's best! If you like Thai food, this one is a must.
author: Arek O.

description: It's all about the Crying Tiger salad and the taro fries!  This place is super yummy with good service... wish it was closer to my house!
author: Jen J.

description:
I hesitated between 3 stars and 4 and I decided to go for 4 stars. Thep Phanom was my first Thai food experience 7 years ago and I have spent so many incredible dinners in this place that it deserves well its 4 stars.

The location is nice (a nightmare to park your car though) and the waiters can be really fun (especially when you stay later on a Saturday) and friendly.

The food was amazing 7 years ago, and made me love thai food. I fill that it went a little bit downhill recently and deserves more a 3 and a half star. Still, larb is good, tom yum soup as well and the red curries or the fried tofu tastes the way they should (and do it Thailand).

A safe bet, where you'll spend a good moment in a cool neighborhood.
author: Pascal L.

description: Visited this place on my short vacation to SF. At first, the food was ok. I have had much better Thai. But then my friend and I got food poisoning within 1 hour of eating there. BIG NO NO.
author: Marlen M.

description: This place rocks! The Three's company is amazing and the pumpkin curry is simply divine! The wait staff is friendly, food presentation is excellent, and the restaurant is beautiful. What is not to like? They even play 80's classics arranged as jazz ballads...classy.
author: Uma M.

description: I think this is my favorite Thai place in the city. I've found tha the specials tends to be much better than the standard menu.
author: Ben L.

description: Loved the clay pot chicken...crowded but found all the dishes to be superb.
author: James V.

description:
Thep Phanom is where I go when I'm bored of the usual Thai food. Being on the West Coast makes finding decent Thai food pretty easy, but everyone pretty much does the same menu, the same way. Not so with Thep Phanom.

The chef had western culinary training, and this definitely shows in both the menu and cooking. This is not your "traditional" Thai fare, and if I wanted Thai food that reminded me of what I grew up with, then I'd go elsewhere. I'm not so much of a foodie that I can name the spices from a single spoonful, but all the dishes I've had here had such complex flavours, which made everything so much more interesting to me. I'm not normally a big fan of Tom Yum (too one note: hot), but theirs was light with tasty afternotes of sour, citrus, and grassy. The Titanic Beef (one of their signature dishes) is wonderfully tender and I always think that there's something French about it, in a good way. And I love it that I can choose creme brulee for dessert.

The eclectic influences seem to manifest in the decor as well: traditionally garbed staff amidst a cozy homely interior that is flanked by a small bar. It is always packed, so reservations are recommended or try to get in right when they open.
author: Alberto V.

description:
This is our regular Thai place whenever we think about Thai food in bay area. So felt no excitement to write the review.  But it's so good and there is a need to share it with other people.

The place is neat and full of a lot of Thai decorations even in the restroom.
Their iced tea is our drink every time.  We especially like its aluminum cup.  We tried their Tom Yum Goong and Tom Kha Pak.  I got caught once by the little green pepper in the soup and my mouth was on fire!!!  The soup would be our choice again but I just need to remember not to touch the green pepper.  We also tried their curry chicken.  It's mild and tasteful.  Pad Thai is our choice all the time since it's the best we have ever had.  The dancing lady would be a choice if you liked prawn.  The must choice is the Crispy Fried Portobello Mushroom.  And you wouldn't find it in other places.

Basically everything there is good and you won't go wrong with any dish.  The only difference is spicy level.  Every time we stick with some dishes we like and experience 1 or 2 new thing.  Never get bored with their menu.

We love this place and it becomes our most favorite Thai restaurant since the first visit.
author: Ile F.

description: We ducked in here to escape the rain and eat something warm and got a very good meal.  We had one of the soups (not sure which, I didn't order it) and the vegetarian pumpkin curry.  I'm a sucker for pumpkin curry in general, but this was memorable.  The atmosphere is cozy and the service is very friendly and attentive.  Altogether a very good experience.
author: Ethan S.

description:
Feels like a more authentic Thai experience than most in the city.  The veggie fresh spring rolls are great, but only served on Friday and Saturday nights, disappointingly.

Better to go with a small group where you can share many options.  The Thaitanic Tofu is pretty good.  Servers very polite.  Do not order the Tamarind fish unless you're prepared for the full fish, head and all, to arrive on a plate!  The few times we have been there both seem semi-overpriced for what you get.

A decent Thai option, but nothing remarkable about this place.  And parking sucks.
author: Tamra K.

description: A long-time favorite of mine, really great and extensive menu, lots of  specials make it a great place to try lots of new things. I've always found the food to be great. One drawback is that, over the years, it seems the prices have crept upward. It's no longer the cheap and great Thai restaurant, now it's a bit spendy, I think due to its continuing popularity. To my annoyance, that popularity also means the wait can be long, when back in the day you could come here on a weekday and get seated. Now be prepared for a slog.
author: Art K.

description: I've been going here since they first opened, and I still think it's some of the best Thai food in the Bay Area. The yellow chicken curry is my favorite, and the spicy fish (which you can get either whole or fillet) is also absolutely good. We're blessed with a lot of Thai Restaurants around here, but Thep Phanom continues to set the standard for me.
author: Bret W.

description:
I think the somewhat mediocre reviews are a knee-jerk reaction to the reputation this place has built up.

They've won numerous awards, which they proudly display on the walls.

As a vegetarian, I am always in heaven.
author: Soma L.

description: I love this place... I have never had a bad dish... and I have eaten here at least 100 times... I bring all my outta town friends here and everyone seems to enjoy it... has been my standard that I hold all others to... the price has gone up over the years but I do not care... good portions and great service... and the food is well... 5 stars
author: joshua b.

description:
Someone in Thep Phanom's management has decided to save money for real.

They have raised the prices, reduced the rice portions,  the staff is constantly pushing you to order more and the heater has been shut down no matter how cold it is outside.    

That's too bad because the food is decent, but until they come back to being the cheap and friendly neighborhood restaurant they once were, I won't be coming back.
author: Tommy D.

description:
I love the fact that people give this place 1 or 2 stars, because that means I'll never have to wait for a table...and it won't be as crowded (it is pretty small).  I can spend that time looking for parking...ugh.

Yes, this place is more expensive than other Thai places...but this isn't fast-food Thai, people.  I've been to that other Thai place that's supposed to be good where you take your shoes off and the portions are minuscule.  I've been to the other thai place around the corner from Thep Phanom, I've been to 2 Osha restaurants (talk about overpriced), and I've tried at least 5 others in the city.  This is the best one by far, and their service is great.  How many restaurants nowadays actually change out your silverware after your appetizers...?

My favorites are appetizer #1 (forget the name) these fried corn and chicken dumplings...the pumpkin prawn curry...the crispy duck (warning-must like duck fat)...and last night I had the whole fish with the spicy ginger and garlic sauce.  It was cooked perfectly.

And...I LOVE the fact that this place has DESSERT.  Ok, they may not be Thai, but I don't care.  The Kahlua Creme Brule is amazing...I get it every time.  My boyfriend had the Bananas Foster, which was still good, but not as good as my creme brulee.

So you people that want the "McDonald's" of Thai food--keep giving this place low ratings so there's more room for the rest of us.
author: fi l.

description: This place rocks. Not your usual Thai place, so when you are here try something new! The larb ped and beef strips are the best!
author: Q L.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant in town. Yummy !! Crying Lady Rocks!!
I have friends that work here, so my food/service is always great.....so I feel bad for those who didn't like it.
author: Meagen H.

description: I tried this place for delivery recently. My usual Thai restaurant was not delivering so I decided to try something new.  I really, really regret ordering from here. The Pad See Ew was DISGUSTING. The moment I took it out of the bag I could smell the burnt noodles, and it tasted charred as well.  We ended up throwing out both of our FULL noodle dishes (for $11 each) and going hungry- that means it had to be really bad, as we were starving by the time it was delivered. The chicken wings were good- but plain, no sauce comes with them.  I would stay away from this place- even Chili Cha Cha is better (and I don't love that place).  Thailand Restaurant in the Castro is 5 times better than this place, so I would recommend going there instead.
author: M H.

description: You get really attentive service and really delicious food here.  The tom kha goong (spicy & sour coconut soup) is soooo good, I could eat it by the gallon.  I've been here several times now and I really love everything I've had.  It's a tiny bit more spendy than some Thai places but worth it.  Go there.  Take a friend.  Have some tea and sit and gossip for hours.  :)
author: Emily T.

description: Okay, I *CRAVE* this place.  Whenever I come back to SF, this is the first place I go.  Their crispy basil with tofu is is to die for and the coconut soup is nummy nummy.  I wish their vegetarian selection was a little better-- even their peanut sauce has fish sauce in it so I can't eat it.  If you're vegetarian, make sure you tell them that so they can let you know exactly what you're eating.  All I can say is that if I could eat here on a weekly basis, I totally would.
author: Nicci S.

description: My friend picked Thep Phanom for dinner last Saturday and it did not disappoint! Bold flavors and fresh ingredients!  I had the "wailing lady", which has eggplant with chicken in equal parts.  Chicken is minced and spiced to perfection!  My husband's curry was also outstanding.  The portions are just right - not too big and not too small.  This place is not very big and it was crowded.  Luckily my friend made a reservation. We shared a bottle of wine, since they only serve beer and wine.  Overall a great dinner!
author: Lidiya B.

description: Not as good as it probably once was. Would avoid. Chicken was overcooked, mushrooms were undercooked. Good service, good price, but the food leave much to be desired.
author: Guy B.

description:
this place has been operating since 1986. 

lots of unique dishes. i love the duck salad and the jumbo prawns in a special curry sauce with broccoli and cauliflower. 

the interior decor is awesome and the service is good. 

more pricey than most thai places.
author: Yevi A.

description: I'd give this place a 5 star if it wasn't so damn expensive.  Ok its not super expensive but its a little much for what you get.  The food is amazing though.  Once something like that hits your taste buds you never forget it.  I've tried so many dishes here and have taken so many people here its not even funny.  I've tried the pad thai, weeping lady, many soups, and tons of chicken dishes.  Everything is AMAZING!!  I went to thailand a month ago and this food was better than what I got out there.  That probably means its more fattening and maybe not as authentic as "real" thai food but I'm sorry,  it tastes damn good.  The service is as great as the food.  These ladies wear real thai outfits.  Now that has to be a bitch.  Seriously...If I wore a long tight skirt like that I'd trip all over myself.  Check out the food though :)  You won't regret it!
author: karla k.

description:
Every Thai restaurant basically has the same stuff. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Panang never really sucks. 

But this place has stuff you won't find elsewhere. 

The Titantic chicken that everyone writes about is worth the trip. There was a pretty good salt and pepper beef special that wasn't all that salty or pepper, but was still tasty.

One ding is that I'd read that this place was spicy, but it ain't. If you want something spicy ask for it. 

It's not cheap either, but the portions are big. You can easily get away with 3 entrees for a party of 4. 

There's more than enough cheap, good Thai in the city. It's cool to have something a little better.
author: hart l.

description: The food is definitely delicious here, but I think you can get better Thai for your money in SF (dishes are probably about $2 more here than my fave over in my hood, Silver Spoon Thai, or Marnee Thai, also very well known like Thep Phenom but cheaper). That said, they have a prix fix and free glass of wine going for their anniversary right now.
author: Shoshana D.

description: For long-time fans, there's no denying they sadly seem to be on a downward spiral . . . with the passing of time, prices have increased, portions have gotten smaller, and the once consistently above-average quality has become merely so-so.
author: Gourmet G.

description: great food, been around for years, when i used hang around the haight this was my food of choice
author: DJ Y.

description: I would give this place one star, but the food did seem fresh and clean and the service was pretty good. this is not the thai place to go to if you are vegetarian- I believe the amazing reviews for it are about its seafood- don't expect to get anything but mundane pad thai or veggie dishes.
author: Liz S.

description: Once again, Thai food that's over $7 a dish doesn't compute. The food is actually quite tasty, but the portions are small for the price you're paying. The nature of Thai food (at least the dishes I prefer to dine on) is cheap, fast and often very greasy. That's just the way I like it. Classing it up is just unnecessary.
author: Viv C.

description: Hands down THE BEST Thai restaurant in the city. Other places PALE IN COMPARISON. The food is awesome. The service is warm and inviting. I like that the rice is served in a traditional serving bowl and dished out for you at the table. I also appreciate any restaurant that uses linen tablecloth settings on their tables. Eating here is always a memorable experience, and it's so close to where I live - lucky me!
author: NirvAnna M.

description: This place serves really great americanized, overpriced Thai food. Sorry to break it to you, but real Thai food tastes better and spicier.
author: Karen C.

description: Eh. I had heard so many great and wonderful things about this place but sadly it didn't seem to live up to the hype at least in my experiences dining there. The portions are tiny and the price is a bit high. It's almost like they're trying too hard to be somewhat upscale. There are plenty of other better Thai places in the city in my opinion.
author: Kimi W.

description:
I've had SO much better Thai for SO much less that I have to give this place only two stars.  The spicy basil chicken I had there recently was tough and bland - it tasted like deep fried chicken skin, not the actual meat.  

When you charge almost twice what other Thai restaurants charge, you'd better be a hell of a lot better...and certainly not worse! I may give this place another try if they lower their prices but otherwise, forget it.
author: Joseph S.

description: It was ok.  My dish of sauteed chicken was fresh and the jasmin rice good.  It was expensive, though, for what we got.  The service was very friendly.
author: Lauren S.

description: Thep Phanom is a definite winner- despite reports of it not being as good as it once was.  To me it seems they have struck a solid balance b/w fine authentic taste, good ingredients and a cozy yet refined atmosphere.  The curries and seafood combos are delicious and the Thep specials will not disappoint you, i suggest the 'Crying Lady'- Jumbo prawns and the Thaitanic beef.  Fried whole tilapia and the fillet with spicy sauce are great. Amongst the appetizers the boneless stuffed wings and Tod Mun are amongst my favs.  Anytime the chef has made efforts to de-bone chicken wings and re-stuff them with glass noodles and black mushrooms you know you are in for a treat. The soups are family size portions so come with a group of 4.  They also have beer, wine and some uninspired desserts.
author: Akash D.

description: Considered to be "Royal Thai", and not the casual fare served in the Tenderloin. Very elaborate menu and a huge selection of daily specials. Extra care is taken in providing this food goes beyond the take-out level. And it does. Dont miss their chicken satay, yellow curry chicken or even their pad thai washed down with one of their Thai beers or Thai iced tea. Beautifully decorated in authentic Thai regalia.  Always crowded, and a bit small, so make sure reservations are made if there are four or more.
author: Mick F.

description: We love this place! The food is phenomenal and the staff is incredibly friendly. The pumpkin fried moons are to die for, the curry chicken so delicious. The restaurant is always nicely decorated. My husband and I like it so much we had our wedding reception there after our City Hall wedding.
author: Christina G.

description: When we lived in Hayes Valley, we ate here at least every other week.  Great Thai food. Consistently good, too.
author: Jason B.

description: The best Thai I've found in SF so far. The curry, fried rice and noodle dishes are all solid and exceptionally fresh tasting. Pad See Ew with duck is to die for.
author: Emanuel K.

description: I feel like I might be reviewing the wrong place based on the other reviews but it was on Waller.  Anyway, I thought the menu looked impressive but the food itself was underwhelming.  The atmosphere was nice and the staff was friendly but that didn't make up for the fact that my curry was bland.  Plus I ordered the yellow curry with ONIONS and potatoes and there was one piece of onion in the whole thing.  Finally the wine tasted just wrong which as anyone knows from reading my reviews can make or break a place for me.
author: Lindsay P.

description:
This is a good place to go if you like to wait to get in and wait to get your food, or if you don't mind ordering to go and waiting an hour to pick it up. Basically this is a Thai place for patient people who aren't terribly hungry. If you've just had a snack it's probably a perfect place for dinner!
Don't get me wrong, the portions are fairly good, especially since the prices are a bit on the steep side. It's a classy place though and the service seems pretty good and friendly.
We had a mourning event and ordered a bit of everything, the steak salad, the glass noodles w/chicken, spicy pork with green beans, larb (dontcha just love saying that word? larb...) and an intimidatingly large 'jumbo shrimp' stuffed with crab and served atop a grilled pineapple -fun on a stick! The rest of the crew raved about the glass noodles, but I just found it ok. I've been here a handful of times over the years and it's fine, but they should work on the 'turn and burn' idea so people can get in and out at a better pace.
author: Colleen B.

description: Last nite, I had dinner at this place. Someone said it was the best Thai in SF. I have lived in the neighborhood since 2004 and I knew there was a reason, I never went here. Serves me right for listening to people who probably have never been to Asia, or had really really good Thai food. The food was ok but definitely not the best Thai in SF.
author: Jay S.

description: Probably the best Thai place in lower Haight.  Nice presentation, ambiance, service, and decent food.  The prix fixe menu that they have (had?) was a great deal.  They have brown rice and the appetizers are pretty delicious (and nicely presented.)
author: Neil G.

description: I found the food to be way to pricey for what it was, plus if you are a vegetarian this is the most vegetarian-unfriendly Thai place I have been to. I think you need to like seafood to know why this place gets a high rating.
author: Jerry S.

description: Excellent... I came here when I was under the weather, and their hot veggie coconut milk soup hit the spot perfectly.
author: .V X V.

description: Standard fare thai food, but a small service complaint -- they rushed us out of the restaurant because it was late on a Saturday night.  First they asked us to pay our bill already; that's fine, we understand the wait staff have somewhere to be.  But then literally a minute later a waiter came by and asked us if we have paid yet just as we were getting our wallets out.  That annoyed us.
author: Jesse C.

description: Thep Phanom is fairly good, but it isn't authentic. Mind you, the crowds who line up to eat here don't seem to care.
author: Stellah D.

description:
Let's first rewind to 2000 when I ate there last. 
I had reunited with my half brother & half sister for the first time in YEARS just a few months prior.  My Brother had frequented this place in the late 80's when it was 1/3 its current size (yes, it was THAT small).  THe place had grown to be one of most prized Thai place in the City.  My brothers, sister & I decided to come out here for dinner  one evening in 2000.   I was fortunate to have been able to witness the fine cuisine I was told about so much.  

  Fast forward to tonight.  Although many of their dishes are unique and delicious (and the standards are good as well) it just wasn't the same eye-popping tongue-dancing experience I remembered in 2000.  I know the owners are still the same, because the owners know my brother very well.  We were given a very friendly welcome into the restaurant and the owners even gave us a few appetizers on the house!  The ambience is the same beautiful authentically decored mini palace as it was 7 years ago.  Their beef with basil was scrumtious and I also enjoyed the duck!  However, having the expectation I had from remembering my 2000 experience took one star from my rating Thep Phanom.  I would expect a reputable establishment like this to continue serving their food consistently over time.  But being that Thep Phanom holds a special place in my heart for the occassions I've been there with my brothers & sister should definately earn them two of the four stars.  The Thai food is authentic and delicious, but don't expect to be overly blown over, unless they come back to their original recipes.

Dishes we were served tonight:

- Lemon Grass Salad - Chicken & Shrimp with cashew nuts, lemon grass, & spicy lemon dressing. ***
- "The Crying Tiger" - Grilled Beef Salad with Spicy Garlic Dressing *****
- Panang Chicken - ****
- Nan Kruan (" The Weeping Lady") - Chicken with grilled eggplant garlic, chili, and basil. ***
- Salt & Pepper Crispy Beef Strips - with cashews and crispy basil *****
- Ped Sawan - Boneless duck in honey sauce over spinach. *****

(the "*'s" were my star ratings for each dish).
author: Gio G.

description: I love good food.  Especially Thai food.  After being introduced to this little corner restaurant, it might be on of my favorite Thai joints around.  Beautiful dishes, very delicious.  We got the green papaya dish, no hint of shrimpiness....points there, a Talapia dish, and if I can remember correctly an eggplant  dish.  Well attended to, food great, company great, wine great. How many times was that great?  Ever dish that I saw being served looked superb, and the other reviews here only confirm my taste buds and impression
author: ERICA E.

description:
the food here hit the spot after a long day at work.  my co-workers and i shared some chicken coconut soup, spicy prawn salad, beef and spinach in peanut sauce, and prawn, scallops & calamari in coconut sauce... 
our order came out pretty fast and the flavors were great.  it was filling too so we had no room for dessert.
prices are super reasonable and the service was attentive and friendly.  they kept coming to the table to refill our waters... and asking if we wanted more drinks or food/desserts etc...
it's also a cozy dining room with various thai decorations.  the waitstaff wears a thai inspired uniform as well...
we were lucky and got rockstar parking for our 6pm dinner too~ :)
author: charlotte s.

description: Not the cheapest Thai place, but the vegetarian entrees are delicious.  Veggies: skip the appetizers!  The entrees such as the thaitanic tofu and the breaded portabella mushrooms and eggplant are DELICIOUS.  The service is just as good as the food.   Weekends and prime dinner times equal long waits!!!
author: Lisa L.

description:
i hadn't been here in a zillion years until friday night when i returned to find that they are still living up to the standards they set when they were "THE" thai place in sf.
we had the titanium beef which was delic and the spicy chicken w. basil which was a little dry but still tasty.  they also served real brown rice, as opposed to the brown colored white rice that i've found in other thai restaurants.
the wines by the glass were decent.
the staff was friendly and they wore really cool traditional thai dresses. 
dinner was followed by drinks in the lower haight and we were surprised to find that most of the bars are beer and wine only.  i have lived in the hood for over a year and i had no idea.  shows how much time i spend in bars.
overall- great experience.
author: Mary C.

description:
Really liked the food here...

Dishes I enjoyed:  Vegetarian spring rolls, lemongrass tofu with jasmine rise, creme brule, jasmine tea

Dish I didn't enjoy: fillet of fish with green curry...served on a whole fish with its tail sticking up, the fish was dry and somewhat tasteless

Overall a great experience here
author: Michele Y.

description: Great salmon curry dish and nice atmosphere.
author: Petko M.

description:
A friend and I tried Thep Phanom on a Tuesday night and we were seated very promptly after we arrived.  The atmosphere in the restaurant is very cozy and the two of us felt immediately comfortable. The wait staff was attentive and our order arrived very quickly. For an appetizer we ordered the Tod Mun Plah (fried fish cake) which was good, and the cucumber salad garnish went very well with it. I'm not sure if I would order it again, though.
Our first entree was "The Weeping Lady" (Sauted minced chicken with grilled eggplant , garlic , chili and basil ) and it was amazing.  The dish is extremely spicy, so caution to those who can't take a little heat.  The minced chicken and grilled eggplant go very well together, the textures complimenting eachother perfectly.
We also ordered the Panang Nuer.  It's pretty difficult to screw up a panang curry dish, and Thep Phanom's dish was definitely up to par, but didn't really offer anything that I haven't seen at other thai restaurants as far as this dish goes.  That's not to say it was bad - panang curry is one of my favorites and this dish certainly satisfied.
All in all, our dinner here was a very enjoyable experience.
author: Gerald V.

description: It's not the most consistent place but a reliable standby. I wish it were a touch cheaper but it's a safe bet.
author: Eric M.

description: For a while this place was raved about as the best Thai in San Francisco.  Naturally, I had to come here.  They have tried to cater to an American crowd but they will also make authentic food.  Every time I come I ask them to make the whole fried fish and serve it whole, as they typically fillet it for customers.  It was incredible.  They prepare it with some unique spices that are different from the traditional preparation and it tastes great!    Do not try to recreate this in your home wok unless you are very experienced.
author: apple r.

description: I think it's all atmosphere. Seriously, cute place but the Thai food wasn't all that impressive. I'd take Osha Thai, atmosphere-free, any day.
author: Sarah R.

description: Delicious thai food. Pretty expensive. Really nice wait staff. The lemon grass chicken is awesome. I have gotten some really bland dishes here too.
author: kristen l.

description: After hearing from multiple people that this is the best Thai in the city, I was completely underwhelmed.  The food just wasn't very good.
author: Cully W.

description:
Overpriced food that was mediocre at best! 
Service was lame and neither friendly nor unfriendly.
My food came 10 minutes before my friends food and i was luke warm.
We spent $ 75 for two persons- that included 2 appetizers, 2 entrees and one glass of wine! Totally overpriced! I so do regret having spent the money! 
Will never go back there!
author: Nicole W.

description:
i have passed this place a number of times on my trek from Toronado to Zeitgiest.  i always point it out and say a little too loudly, "ooooo i want to try that plaaaace."  so, when my mom came into the city to hang out, i jumped on the opportunity to try it.

i was very surprised when i walked in. first of all, i always thought it was just another hole in the wall... but it was.. kinda fancy.  (i was not prepared for this and rather underdressed.) it was sleek and the service was almost too attentive.

everything on the menu sounded pretty good and it took a really long time to finally decide to start with the grilled octopus and then we split the grilled quail and red curry duck. 

i would not suggest getting the thai iced tea, it's way too small a serving.  i would suggest the phuket beer, which has a totally sweet label. 

everything was very strongly flavored which i loved.  the grilled octopus was spicy, acidic and tender.  and the red curry with duck was perfect.  not overly spicy, just a little heat with incredibly tender duck and warm cherry tomatoes that would burst into deliciousness with the red curry.  the grilled quail was superb, with tender little birds with crispy basil, onions and mushrooms.  

i don't know how authentic it is.  but honestly, i could give a rat's ass about authentic.  delicious food is delicious.  and this food is definitely delicious. 

i will definitely be back there, but it's not a hole-in-the-wall cheap thai eats.  it's a little more upscale in ambiance and in price.  but well worth it.
author: Ge O.

description: I tried the green curry, Beef Thaitanic, and mango/sticky rice dessert.  The green curry was ok but nothing to write home about (but then again, when is it ever?).  As a side note, the a la carte sticky rice portions are pretty small.  The Beef Thaitanic was disappointing and tasted like something I'd get at a Chinese restaurant, not a Thai one.  I don't know why I ordered the Thaitanic and only ordered it based on the waitress's recommendation.  The mango/sticky rice was way overpriced, the portion was TINY (the amount that fits in a hollowed mango half), was overly sweet, and doused in a sweet coconut liquid.  The meal came out to about $25 a person and in my opinion, was a bit too much.  Worth a visit, but expect to pay more than you normally do.
author: David L.

description:
"What's your budget?" our friend asked, as we were in the area and wanted dinner fast - "$50, including drinks - for both of us".

Thep was the recommendation - and it was good Thai food. Not great, but solidly good. We had the Thep salad (very fresh), Tom Kha Gai soup (not spicy enough), and some kind of fish in banana leaves.

The space is festive - they're celebrating their 20th anniversary and balloons and plastic leis served as additional decoration. Pretty paper tie-dyed place mats too...we took ours home. Free art!

Including two drinks, bill (including tip) came to $49.37.
author: Allie W.

description: After wandering around Lower Haight for 30 minutes one lazy Sunday and vetoing various cuisines one by one, my friend and I settled upon Thai and came across Thep Phanom. It was fantastic. Their coconut vegetable soup may well be laced with Ecstacy, it was that good. This is a great place to go when you've already been to Osha ten times and want something new and different, and don't feel like getting peed on by a homeless person on the way to your dinner.
author: Nick A.

description: I really like this place. All the veggies are very fresh, and the curries are good. I usually get the green curry with basil and zucchini and I love it. I also really like their Tom Yum. The vegetarian one is packed full of veggies and they will make it without fish sauce, so it feels very healthy and clean. Cute place, good service.
author: Amanda D.

description: Simply my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Steph S.

description: Fantastic Presentations, and Killer Flavors from all the dishes offered and tasted.  Service is warm and friendly, the wine list is not to shabby for a thai restauant truth be told, and i only live a block away.  It is a win win for everyone.
author: brian m.

description: Used to be great, but lately the quality and portion size seems  to have gone down.  The food si still pleasant, but not fantastic.  And the atmosphere is crowded and noisy.
author: Gisela S.

description: Small, crowded, difficult neighborhood parking and truly delicious food. "Thep Phenomenal" is among my favorites. I just wish they would open for lunch. Try it. You'll love it.
author: Hale J.

description: Phenomenal Thai food in a living room setting, which is always crowded and a little cramped. Arrive early, or have reservations, or both, and hope your parking karma is good, since it's in the Lower Haight. Have been here a few times, most recently Jan 2006. I like the lab ped (minced duck meat), the tom yum gai (spicy and sour chicken soup), the massee weepayoke (broiled catfish), the kaeng moo (sliced pork in red curry paste), the sam kasatr (sauteed beef, chicken, and pork with bamboo shoots), the pork with green curry (just ask for it and they'll make it!), ped sawan (marinated boneless duck), the moo prig pao (sauteed pork), and the choo-chee plah (catfish filet). Authentic Thai since 1986.
author: Hao L.

description: Every dish I end up having there is full of different, unique flavors.  Pricier than your typical Thai place but definitely worth it.
author: Tanger T.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant in san francisco. Almost everything on the menu is amazing except for their pad thai. My favorite is the south sea (eggplant seafood dish). The basil salmon and their curries are also wonderful. 
the ambiance is great as well. It's very tastefully decorated with a lot of attention to detail. I highly recommend it!
author: Julie H.

description: Thep Phanom certainly feels like a place where you would take a date, but I probably wouldn't go out with the dude again if he took me here because it would telegraph to me, "I don't know good Thai food!"  My roommate and I agreed it was time to check out this restaurant in our hood, and we found all three dishes we tried (Tom Kha Goong, The Crying Lady, and Veggie Pad Thai) to be on the sweet side, none too bold or memorable.  The Crying Lady was crab-stuffed shrimp that was impossible to eat without making a mess, so do avoid if you're trying to impress someone.  Overpriced and underspiced.
author: Patricia D.

description: I've liked what I've ordered here.  If anything needs a little more 'oomf' for me, I'll add some more pepper, fish sauce, sugar, and lime juice if the dish calls for it.  If dishes start out decent, they can be better by adding those little things.  It is a pretty small place, but I never had a problem with waiting long for table.
author: Pamela S.

description: Best thai in SF.  It was way cuter before the remodel when it felt like you were in someone's home or place of worship.  OIt looks too modern now, but the food is still fantastic and so ids the service.
author: Danielle B.

description: Really tasty and spicy Thai cuisine. Don't be a wuss and turn the menu over and get the spicy entrees. It is so worth it. Their portions are pretty big, too, so if you're not too hungry just split one menu item. It's more than enough, and man it's so good. The decor is pretty cool as well, in a nice cozy setting.
author: Michael E.

description:
I guess SF didn't have a lot of Thai restaurants for a long time, which must be why for years after I moved here from LA  this place seemed to be regarded as "Best Thai in SF."  (LA, on the other hand, was already full of hole-in-the-wall Thai places with good food).  After giving it numerous opportunities, time to write a review.

Overpowering smell of fish sauce as you enter is not a good sign.  Food is so-so, seating cramped.  All of this, I suppose, added an air of the unusual or exotic to it.  

If you don't know any better, you might like this place.  But it's not very good.
author: Ritch G.

description: The food is always amazing. Go on a Wednesday or Thursday for their special "Siamese Twins" It is a geat seafood combination in a beautiful handmade banana leaf basket thingee. The Dancing Lady plate is shrimp stuffed with crab. Yum.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Thep Phanom is quite possibly the best Thai restaurant in SF. Every meal that I have had there has been memorable, delicious and well presented. The decor is nice, very elegant for the price range. For about $60, we got an appetizer (calamari), yellow curry chicken, salmon, and a few beers. The calamari was chewy but not at all tough, and the chicken and salmon perfectly prepared. Everything was tasty, and we had plenty of food for two people (possibly enough for three).
author: Dana L.

description: We've eaten here many times and had absolutely delicious meals most times. In particular they do very flavorful sauces. Gracious staff. Love it. Worth a few extra bucks. Watch out for the $3 iced teas though, they are tiny and tasty.
author: Tom L.

description: This is my neighborhood Thai place and my favorite in the city... go early 'cause it gets a little crowded.
author: Chris M.

description: Tasty Thai food, with an awesome atmosphere.  Try their curries!
author: Corey C.

description: I'm surprised I haven't written about Thep Phanom already.  This is absolutely one of my favorite restaurants.  I've always had delicious meals and rarely order the same thing.  I like to come with at least two others so that we get a variety of dishes.  Thep Phanom is one of the most important stops in my visits to San Francisco and one of the places I'm most looking forward to being near when I move back.  (Crispy tofu: yum)
author: Susannah R.

description: Thep Phanom has a somewhat elegant atmosphere, good service and good food.  The best part of the restaurant is the beautiful presentation of the food.  From the appetizers to the main dishes, everything looks picture perfect.  I went with a large group of people, so I was able to sample a lot of different dishes.  My favorite dishes were two red curry based dishes (a chicken & eggplant red curry and a pumpkin and shrimp red curry).  The vegetable and tofu in the peanut sauce was pretty good, but not a stand out.
author: Matt P.

description: I have been dining at Thep Phanom for years and it rarely disappoints. While not as experimental as some of the newer hip Thai places that have been springing up. it is eons better than most of your neighborhood Thai restaurants. Whenever I want take out, this is my go to, even though I have two Thai restaurants within 3 blocks of my house. I would rather make the trek or order delivery from Thep Phanom.
author: Katherine B.

description: I've only have been here once but it was really good and I think how traditional Thai food tastes, like for example, the fried quail, which was really interesting tasting but had no real meat on it. Meh, quails are small. But wow, were the curries and appetizers tasty! I will go back when I'm not broke! Oh and the presentation of the food is really artistic!
author: Gina R.

description: Although it's a bit pricey, I have never been disappointed.  This is definitely my favorite Thai food in San Francisco.
author: Melaina E.

description: We are so lucky to have Axum, Indian Oven and Thep Phanom in our 'hood.  Even though sometimes you have to put on a bullet proof vest to get there, it's well worth it!  Thep Phanom is great for dining in or take out.  I love the Goong Siam (prawns with curry and roasted veggies) or lemon grass tofu and my husband really digs the Kaeng Karee Gai (chicken in mild yellow curry paste with onions and potatoes) or the very authentic "crispy beef sticks."  I say if you can't have beef on a stick, why bother?
author: Julie B.

description: Sad what success has done to this place.  The food is not what it used to be.  Maybe one star is a bit harsh, but I'm very disappointed in their fall from grace and resting on laurels.
author: Jenn S.

description: I love there roasted crispy duck!!! I have an infatuation with duck!  The silver noodles was okay.  I think I just like there duck dish the most.  Tucked in between Fillmore and Waller street this restaurant is a neighborhoodie restaurant in the Haight district!
author: Jboogie L.

description:
a friend of mine raved about this place. and by raved, I mean, she said,

'oh yeah this place is Hella good...'

now by her using the word, 'hella' this should've been indication that she was being far too generous. and yet, she was.

I'm no genuis when it comes to the cuisines but my tongue knows what it likes and knows what it doesn't like and this place was hit or miss on too many occasions.

we did a family style by ordering multiple dishes and just eating off each other plate. which was better bc my choice and I won't say it by name, was not very thrilling nor did it really get my heart going,

but its not all bad. good presentation, good service. so I wouldn't mind going back. not all of the dishes were bad. the soup was amazing, I'll admit. so there is room for improvement in my review upon another visit. I believe its good.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description:
they dont have chopsticks!!#!@#!!

3
i'd say average thai food.
the green curry is pretty good. creamy.

the tom yum gai was not as flavorful as id like.  
the prigking tofu was ok.  the string beans were too raw. 
the crying lady- prawns fried and in sauce w veggies was the least favorite.
the pad thai was average also.

the thai ice coffee did not have enough milk. 
the price is kinda high for the quality. but maybe that's just sf.
author: Heejin L.

description: I'm a big Thai food fan.  The food at Thep Phanom was good - not exceptional, but certainly tasty enough.  The prices, however, far exceeded the value of the product.  The service was decent, though also not fantastic.  I was incredibly put off when I asked for chopsticks and received a disdainful, condescending look and the response that "we do not serve with chopsticks."  The wait-staff, in general, was brusque and not particularly friendly.  All together, the high price, the lack of friendliness, and the non-exceptional food combined to create an experience that made me miss other Thai places in the city.
author: Jon A.

description: I remember having really great memories of Thep Phanom, but I've been back a couple times recently and just haven't been that impressed.  The food is just ok and it's a little on the pricey side compared to your average Thai place.  I think the ingredients are good, but the seasoning/sauce just leaves me wanting.  Was there with a couple friends recently and only 1 in 4 of us really liked our meal.  The good one was a veggie dish, tofu and green beans I think.  The biggest disappointment was the crab-stuffed shrimp.  It sounds great in theory, but the crab just wasn't that good and it lacked flavor.  I didn't think the sauce it came with for dipping really fit the dish well either.  There's defintiely better Thai food to be had.
author: Zach J.

description: My lemongrass tofu was good, and I was glad they had fresh rolls on the special menu.
author: Amy E.

description: Disappointing and more expensive than most Thai places we've been to. Thai is my favorite food but while they do some interesting and creative work on presentation, the food was really just not very flavorful.  The pad Thai was and papaya salad were the worst I've ever had and $100 for three of us. Staff were very pleasant. Dining room was pretty packed.
author: Mark C.

description: One of the best Thai restaurants in the city.  The food took a little while to order, but I love the broccoli.  Yum!
author: Joanna S.

description:
My latest visit to this place left me less awed than past visits, say 5-6 years ago.  Now is the food worse, or is it just that I now eat Thai all the time and my standards have changed?  Who can say.
The thing is I had remembered it being phenomenal, mouth watering yummy and it is good, yes it is very good, but this time I was not so blown away.  
The Dancing Ladies, one of their specialties, was great and the grilled pineapple it comes with was a succulent added bonus, but I found the Siamese rolls and our curry dish to be rather ordinary.  Now that being said, the presentation of all of the above was beautiful and this is one thing about Thep Phanom that has always held them a step above most other Thai places for me.
I think I've become a Thai food snob.  See what happens when you live here.  Not that I'm complaining, I had Thai food in Detroit a few weeks ago (at a place that is supposed to be one of the best in town no less) and it paled in comparison to what we get here at your average place.
author: Gucci M.

description: I know everyone loves this place. but having only been here once- a first impression is everything. I thought the service was a little aggressive and bizarre. Also for me, the food was blah. I love that the wait staff wears funky outfits though. that's all i got
author: angela g.

description: Good food, I like their duck salad and crispy squid. I'm from LA, I'm not used to the 45 minute search for a parking spot. Price is a bit on the expensive side. But overall I enjoy dining here
author: Danny R.

description: 3.5 Stars, actually - pretty good, but not fantastic. Had a shrimp spring roll for an appetizer, was OK, but the shrimp in my first one tasted a bit old. Then shared crispy duck, which was good, and prawn and pumpkin red curry, which was very good and well spiced and by far the better of the two entrees. Great Thai Ice Tea, but then again I'm a sucker for just about all Thai Ice Tea. Prices were reasonable, but not a bargain - $50 + tip for two people without drinks. I would go again for the curry, but am definitely in the market for a GREAT Thai place.
author: Scott S.

description:
I must have tried Thep Phanom on an "off" night for service.  Every step of the way our service (2 of us) was terrible.  A simple meal took 2.5 hours.  I'm all for taking my time and enjoying my dining experience, but it was a long wait for everything.  

A long wait and 3 waitstaff later, we finally placed our order after the 4 tables around us that arrived 5-10 minutes after us placed theirs.  This after flagging down 2 of the different wait staff.  Drinks were not refilled.  No one checked in with us after placing our order.  My friend's entree was brought out, mine was brought out 15 minutes later.   It made for an awkward dining experience.  He was partway done when mine arrived.  I am politely assertive, too, and spoke to every waitperson in the place, and it was terrible service through and through.  They did have a large party at the restaurant, but geez!

The food was good, but the poor service greatly took away from Thep Phanom.  I was relieved to finally pay the bill and leave.
author: K V.

description: I don't want to give out too many 5-star ratings but honestly, if you're looking for Thai, this is definitely the best in the city. When I didn't live in this neighborhood I used to come across town to this place. Very casual but the food is exceptional. If you go on Fri or Sat, the fresh spring rolls are compulsory. And if it was socially acceptable, I would bathe in their peanut sauce. All their crazy special dishes (beef thaitanic, the crying lady, etc.) are very good...but the standard Thai dishes like gai karprow (spicy basil chicken) are exceptional.
author: Bill R.

description: My favorite Thai Restaurant in San Francisco!  Everything on the menu is cooked to perfection and delicious, and their specials are always interesting. They have many things to order that you will not find on a typical thai menu--- I suggest the crying tiger beef salad, salmon thaitanic curry (chef special), and the dancing lady (large prawns stuffed with crab meat). Oh--- and the crispy basil beef is one of my favorites too.
author: James M.

description: The way Thai food should be-- the soups spicy and hot with the fresh flavor of lemongrass, cilantro and chili, the meats in sauce creamy and rich, the beer cold and the establishment, intimate, just like someone's home.  Fresh, simple ingredients with depth of flavor . . . Absolutely the best Thai food I have had in the city!
author: regina k.

description: Pretty darn good Thai food, not the best I've ever had, but it's always packed so people must really like it.  They've got some tasty spring rolls!
author: Stephanie P.

description: Tube socks rule!! Seriously this place has it all - fantastic food combined with a great atmosphere. Its a staple location to take out of towners.
author: Inome C.

description: Thai spices in all the right places for my palate, starting from the appetizers, soups and entrees. You have to go a few times to try all of your soon to become faVorites.
author: Angela R K.

description: I not a big fan of Thai, but each time I dine here I come away a satisfied customer. I tend to stick to the prawns, but it is a solid place to eat in Hayes Valley. It is a bit spendy, but the food is delicious.
author: Steve B.

description: Um...hummm... I do agree that there is less expensive Thai food in this city. Not nearly as convent for me, but cheaper and dare say better. I do not have a car. Sometimes you are on your way home from work and want a great heart warming bowl of soup. Thep Phanom filled my belly with hot, spicy coconut milk broth soup and saw me off (with wine) for under $20. If you want to stuff your face, I think there are much more economically friendly places to go. I like this joint. Will come back, probably by myself.... but return none of the less.
author: Charise B.

description: I definitely recommend this place. Every dish we ordered was flavorful and done just right. Their curry is one of the best I've had. It get's busy at night so probably best to go early.
author: Norton W.

description: Go here at least 1/month. Friend recommended it and said it was the best in the city so I tried it. Not cheapest thai (chili cha cha is cheap, good, around the corner) but great presentation and solid job on food. Now one of my favorite thai restaurants in the city, too. Highly recommend it.
author: jey o.

description: Thep Phanom used to be our  favorite culinary stop in SF. The decorative remodel is lovely and only 3 months old but the food quality seems downgraded. We ordered a fish filet, they brought the whole fish out which was bland. The curry was decent but the meat in it a bit chewy. We also ate the crispy duck- it was incredibly dry and the plum sauce too mild. We had to order extra rice and the staff did not even offer dessert choices.  Overall- too expensive for what is given, the two person per table row left us a little too cozy with the strangers to our left and right, and lastly, in a Thai-Asian food restaurant, they don't even carry chopsticks!!!!
author: Eve V.

description: Like Thai? Eat here.  Dishes are deep with flavor.  The chicken yellow curry is rich and the king of comfort food.  Moo Prig Khing is my favorite Thai dish.  I plan on ordering it the next time I visit TP as I'm sure it will be shake a tail feather good!
author: Christina T.

description: Love-Love-Love this place. I'm always pleased when we stop in. My favorite is the lemon grass-coconut shrimp with tomatoes and cabbage.  This is very difficult dish for me to share with the other guests at my table.  So I always order two-- one for the family style sharing thing and one for me!
author: Princess P.

description: To my astonishment, this place has gotten rave reviews from the Chronicle for years and years, before Yelp even existed. I wonder if Michael Bauer has ever eaten here, or eaten here sind 1995? We went here based on the reviews, despite already having a number of affordable Thai faves. I was served the worst inedible rancid red curry dish here and I am scared to return. I sent it back and was treated as if the dish was fine and I didn't know any better. Sheesh, I've been eating Thai food since the 80's. I give two stars for the crispy and better-than-most fried tofu with peanut sauce, but a person cannot live on that dish alone.
author: Paris E.

description:
The first thing I thought when I walked in was, "Oh, great. They put some white tablecloths out, lit some candles, and redecorated within the past decade unlike most Thai restaurants. I'm sure they're going to jack up the prices for these charming touches." SO not true. 

The service was great, the food was plentiful and spiced just right and even had some flair in the presentation. Not every day you get that at a Thai place. I highly recommend the prawns stuffed with crab meat. The Pad Thai is good but generic. Kind of hard to put much of your own spin on it, I guess. Thep Phanom is a little out of my way geographically but I will definitely make my way back there as soon as possible.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Soooo goood. My favorite thai place. The food is amazing and not to mention beautiful. On the menu it says that they consider making food to be an art, this really shows in the preparation. Thaitanic chicken is a must try.
author: Raj M.

description:
wow. ate here last night and was so impressed. 
the food was stunning and spicy. my boyfriend and i agreed 
that we need to bring friends there - especially because it means
we'll get to eat there again. really excellent. 
only bummer was that it took a little while to order and get the
check, but it was pretty busy especially for a monday. 
we had fried shrimp rolls w. plum sauce as an appetizer, which was delicious but the entree was really what did it: fried & spicy portabello mushrooms and giant prawns with green beans and cherry tomato. soooo good. 
anyhow, very tasty, bit pricey, crowded, good vegetarian options.
author: Amber B.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for over 20 years. I've been going to Thep Phanom off and on for years... well, I ate there tonight for the first time in a while and sorry to say, it's my last time.
The service and environment are fine, no complaints.
But it's all about the food with me.
And the food tonight just didn't cut it. In the past, I really thought their food was fresh and so tasty and creative.
I was extremely disappointed. Nothing really tasted fresh. It just wasn't good.  I am so sorry that I wasted any money there tonight.
They are riding on their past reputation.  They need a new chef or something. But the food was just totally off for me and my companion.
I recommend going somewhere else for Thai.
author: jayne a.

description:
we walked over for dinner from a friend's place on a sunday night. cozy restaurant with friendly and efficient staff.  after mulling over the menu, we each decided on the prix fixe 3 course menu and shared the appetizers and the entrees - very good value. normally we would eat everything family style and you can still do that with the prix fixe
appetizers:
fried shrimp rolls, fried corn/taro cakes (the bed of cut cucumbers served as good contrast to all the fried-ness), fried minced chicken - all came with a sweet sauce and were good. 
salad or soup:
crying tiger (sliced beef salad) - good but not great. vegetable coconut soup and chicken coconut soup came in individual small soup bowls and were delicious and soothing - but how can you go wrong with coconut milk in soup?
entrees: you have a choice between white and brown rice (we all got brown)
pumpkin and tofu curry, tamarind chicken (which seemed a bit like sweet and sour chicken) and thaiyeki? steak all came with tasty sauces. my husband got the steak and thought it was particularly tender and cooked just right.
author: Annie c.

description: Thep Phanom has the best Thai food in the city! I brought my friend who is from Chang Mai there & he loved it. The staff is super friendly & really efficient. The best dishes are the spring rolls, Thaitanic Tofu & green curry. Very vegetarian friendly.  Plus, they will make any dish that has chicken or seafood with tofu if you ask!
author: Owl B.

description: Really sub-par service, authenticity and vibe.
